When I first was told about this anime, I had heard the rumors of it being the "gay swimming anime" followed by an iconic trill of giggles. I'm not too into yaoi, so I kept my distance and watched from afar. It wasn't until my friend made it a "must watch" when I decided to test the water, if you will.
First off, this show is not a yaoi (shocker!). It is rather a very well drawn shoujo of a group of friends who just so happen to be shirtless most of the time (for swimming, of course).
The music itself was quite outstanding. What shocked mewas that I had never heard dubstep in an anime before. It matched the show's upbeat tempo and intense races and brought me into what I was watching.


As for character development, there isn't much to show. When I really think about it,  I really don't know anything about these characters other than that they're friends. You learn nothing really personal about these characters, but this is a shoujo. It's sort of to be expected. But if they were to put in more effort then this show would have probably broken through the roof more than it already has.


This is a great show to watch when you are under a lot of emotional stress. The friendship and few adventures they have leave me with such a goofy grin. Though people may watch it for the "fanservice," I watched it for the proportions. At times I thought I was going to cry, and this show isn't even that sad. I was just so friggin happy! Another plus is that this show is most definitely a jab at shows which over-sexualize their female characters. There are a couple female characters in this show and although they are not very prominent, it was a pleasant surprise to not see over-exaggerated breasts. Rather, the show is more focused on the muscular physique of its male characters.


To conclude, I would recommend this show to anyone who likes to smile and doesn't mind thinking too hard about the plot. It's pretty much thrown out there and isn't meant to get too serious. You, as the audience, are supposed to be drawn into what the sole purpose of the show is about: mending broken ties through swimming competition. As my first review on anime, I hope this input helped!

I am a girl and I am not a pervert and I do not watch this anime because of the beautiful characters swimming their bodies and showing the beauty of working out etcetera, etcetera... 
Guilty much?
But Seriously, I hate bulky muscular men as much as I hate large and unrealistic breasts. I'm not really the fanservice loving type.
Which brings us to my review:
To be frank, I've seen the story before. It is much alike to the KNB series and they are both in the sports genre. But I wouldn't want to compare because when I do, things would get a little bit rusty.( Don't worry,no magic and superstitions are applied in this show.) I think the plot is mediocre because it isn't original and the scenes were pretty much predictable and so on and so forth. Some jokes feel flat and some aren't entertaining. A lot of people would say that this show is gay, well, it is. I am quite feeling uneasy while watching this anime. Muscles, water and some expected scenes are showing up. The only unique part of this show is that it used "Swimming" as the main theme. On the other hand, the points and conflicts were too simple, I usually ended up comparing it to other Sport related anime like, Slam Dunk and Kuroko no Basket. I am getting tired of childhood friends seeing one another in the future. Anyway, I watched the whole thing and it was just okay. The great news for fans is that this series will have a new season this coming July. In my opinion, I think the ending is just fine and it went smoothly. There isn't any empty feeling around here. Nevertheless, they don't make hilarious comedic acts that feels awkward all the time in the second season, I don't see any reason why they would not make another season. I just wish they would make the plot more complicated and execute funny moments properly without making it corny. Some jokes are a bit off and becoming repetitive. But then again, all in all it was just okay for me.


Kyoto Animation have been animating great shoujo animes like Clannad and Air and now, Free!, a shiny anime with vibrant particles in many shapes and sizes. The animation is as always modern and fantastic. Who knew water can be so beautiful when animated? The greatness of the characters' eyes were just like Hyouka's. I feel a bit suspicious. The uniforms look tangy and colorful. The swimsuit kinda ruined it for me. But I like the art. It's not the ordinary cartoonic style.


A bit complex and jumpy tones were delivered in all episodes of Free! The opening and the ending were just fine and exquisite to hear. A mix of rock and pop with a bit of athletic speed tempo were present in both songs. There is also a sad piano background music which is for dramatic moments. Others, well not really that outstanding.


Here we go, Characters (5). I personally hate yellow-haired jolly guys so Nagisa isn't one of my favorites. Makoto has a very calm and friendly personality, gentleman of some sort. Rei is practically Narcissistic. Rin has a transition of personalities from grade school to high school and then there's a tsundere guy, Haruka. I do not like tsundere boys and girls but Haruka made the exception. I think he is adorable despite the fact being like Kuroko Tetsuya(but I like Haruka more), and possess some kind of innocent voice and attitude. However I dislike the fact that he and Makoto always hang out and talk about personal and deep stuff and then after ten seconds their faces almost touched and not to mention their lips, I just feel like their hacing yaoi and I really hate yaoi themed animes. Oh, and I feel weird because Makoto's seiyuu is the same seiyuu of Yoshida HARU which is kind of unusual when he calls Haruka, "Haru" when he became Haru. (confused.)


I liked it but not all of it. It is a slice of life kind of anime so it has a friendly approach and a sweet aura. Fillers were seen in a lot of episodes that shouldn't be there. 12 episodes and a lot of fillers? No can do. The jokes were really off and undoubtedly stupid. Gay scenes, Gay scenes everywhere. This is a fanservice for females I think who love gorgeous bodies of men floating and swimming in water with their vibrant hair colors and big bulky muscles. Oh my God, it chills through the spine. I hate fanservice so much!


Overall, I didn't want to drop the whole thing and if I have time, I might sneak a peek at the second season this coming July. I liked the ending, it is happy  not a tragic and not a fugging open ending. Honestly speaking, if you are a straight guy and you feel awkward about watching other guys' beautiful body then don't see this because it has a lot of it. For girls, I think you'll love and hate this series. I think I'll forget this anime someday to the point that it just take up my time but I will recommend it to sports writers and people who can't swim because you will learn something from this anime. At least, you learned something... right?

I actually wanted to give this a 9, but that would mean giving this show the same rating I gave to the first two Rebuild of Evangelion movies and the second season of Ghost in the Shell: SAC. Maybe even an 8 seems absurd, but this anime is exactly what I think a fanservice series targeted towards girls should be: lighthearted, sweet, funny, and loaded with characters that are attractive and easy to fall in love with. 
If this was really just a sports anime, I wouldn't give it such a high score, but honestly...Free! is as much about the muscles and the boys whohave them than it is about the swimming. This anime only happened because people saw KyoAni's mock trailer, which was supposed to be a joke, and literally petitioned for it to be an actual series. In other words, this is made for people who want to watch cute shirtless boys do cute shirtless things with homoerotic subtext, and it fulfills that purpose very well.


Story: 6

I wasn't actually expecting this to have much of a story, but it's there, and it's fun. It's not amazing, but Free! is not something you should be watching for the story. Just ditch it now if you're looking for something sophisticated. Free! isn't complex and it's not supposed to be. It's just fun. Corny, silly, simple, half-naked swimming fun. Unexpectedly, Free! is actually such a funny anime (on purpose). This show really never fails to make me laugh.

Art: 9

Nothing less than what would be expected from KyoAni. The entire thing is gorgeous, and I'm not just talking about the boys. The animation is super fluid (there we go again with the unintentional water puns), bright, colorful, and overall just great. 


Sound: 8

The openings and endings are really enjoyable, especially the first ending song, "Splash Free". The quality of the music is consistent throughout. What bugged me was that during more intense parts of the show (...as intense as the swimming anime can get), there'd be this aggressive dubstep-reminiscent electronic nonsense playing and it was so ridiculous it was funny. It's as if KyoAni was like, "oh, let's pretend this is a serious sports anime for a minute while Rin is gazing into Haru's eyes" and threw in serious music. Still, it didn't sound bad, and when the music is thematically appropriate, it's always good.


Character: 10

The characters are the best part. They all have their strengths, their weaknesses, and their quirks; they're actually very well-rounded, and most experience very satisfying development, especially Rin. They're all very charming characters, and the character that seems to be the simplest out of all of them proves to be more than he seemed in the second season. The boys and Kou are all easy to get attached to and feel for. Also, there's more than a little homoerotic subtext. If you don't think they're gay, you're wrong. KyoAni made a genius business decision in deciding not to have any official couples, but having certain pairs show more-than-friends affection to each other at times. That keeps all the fujoshi ensnared, regardless of who they ship. I see what you're doing, KyoAni. And I don't mind. Keep going.


Enjoyment: 10

When this anime first aired, it was truly the highlight of my week. I'm not exactly a happy person -- I have health issues that keep me down rather consistently -- but my mood was always significantly better on Wednesdays (at least, I think water time was Wednesday). I was just as thrilled with the second season. I watch mostly very dark anime, so Free! was a breath of fresh air. I thought I would forget about this anime after it was done, since it's not exactly intellectual, but I was wrong. This is my go-to when I need something that I can genuinely enjoy at any time. It just doesn't get old for me; it's so full of sweetness, love, and friendship that I can't help but feel happy when I think about it. In fact, I enjoyed Free! more than I enjoyed anime that I rated 10/10.

An anime about swimming... how interesting can it really get? Well yes, the story can be a little simple and sometimes I felt like the series dragged on for longer than it really should have. But for me, the art of this series coupled with the genuine sensitivity behind the story trumps almost everything else (and not just because I'm fangirling over the hot bodies lol!), which is why I believe that Free! is still a unique anime and worth my time watching.
Let's start with the storyline. I thought Free! had a decent story with a relatively rich emotional setting. Three (Makoto, Nagisa and Haru)out of four boys from a childhood swim team are reunited in high school and decide to start a local swim club once more upon discovering that one of their teammates has returned from Australia. The story progresses when we realise there is some conflict between Haru (a somewhat swimming prodigy who is completely obsessed with water) and Rin (portrayed as a super competitive guy) which creates unease amongst the team members of the new swim club, especially with the new member Rei (who is almost like a replacement for Rin). The plot then continues to unravel the mystery behind this tumultuous relationship between Rin and the other boys, and what it means to be part of a team in the past and in the present. 


Of course, the key themes here are friendship and sportsmanship, which I didn't think would appeal to me as a committed shoujou fan. However, the story did somehow draw me in, especially when I learnt about the motivations of the characters (particularly Haru and Rin) and how they've come to be the type of person that they are. Yes there is a huge sports element to it, but sports is not really the point of the story, it's merely a means of communicating the themes of camaraderie and friendship. In that way, even if you're reading this review with the mindset that you're not into sports and this kind of anime wouldn't appeal to you, I would reconsider because swimming is just the setting, and the story of Free! operates within that setting.


Having said that, I feel like there was a lot lacking in terms of the development of the other characters apart from Rin and Haru. You somewhat get to see a deeper side of Makoto and Rei throughout the series, but barely. It feels like the story almost over-focuses on Rin, upto a point where I didn't really see the point of focusing so much on one character when there's a whole cast of other interesting characters as well. And given that the series had a relatively simple storyline, I didn't see how it dragged on to 12 episodes. There were a few fillers in the middle that didn't really add any value to the plot or to the viewer's understanding of the characters, which made me feel like those one or two episodes were almost a waste considering the direction of the whole series. I mean, fillers are fine, but in a 12 episode anime, you would wonder why there is a need to put in fillers when you could put in one or two episodes about the other characters. But eh, it's not that much of a problem in the grand scheme of things, I guess I just get a little frustrated when an anime isn't efficient in terms of using episodes wisely for viewer benefit.


So now on to my favourite part: the art and sound. I simply can't believe how beautiful this anime is! When I watch real life swimming, it has to be one of the most boring and ugliest sports out there (sorry to all those dedicated swimmers, I used to swim a lot too, maybe I just got over it way too quickly). But wow, Free! has really blown my mind in terms of water effects and displaying the fluidity of swimming. I literally feel like I'm relaxing next to a serene pool when I watch this, the art is such a treat to my eyes. And not just because the guys have hot bodies (but no complaints about that, it only adds to the viewing value for girls like me haha!). If there was ever a situation where I could give more than 10/10 for art, this is it. Also, in terms of sound, I found both the opening and ending themes really nice, they fit well with the simultaneously competitive but fun element of the anime. 


All in all, because I was so impressed by the art, and because the story and characters were worth getting attached to, I would definitely rewatch this anime sometime in the future. The experience of watching something so beautiful and exquisite really gave me something to look forward to every week. Maybe it's because I'm the type of person who is very picky about art, but Free! really surpassed my expectations in terms of viewing pleasure whilst also providing a sound storyline.

I must admit that I didn't really want to watch Free, because I was pretty sure that it was all about fanservice and I fucking hate random fanservice, but I promised to my friend to watch it since she said that it was good and I should try out and because I'm the type of person who before judging has to see with her own eyes things I just accepted and I didn't not regret watching it, I swear.
The story isn't anything original but I loved it anyway, I simply loved how this story was even though had just only 12 episodes. 
I truely likedthe characters growth and I loved how this show showed us what means losing and obtain a friend (Rin/Rei). I also liked how they showed the feelings of the characters with expressions. You could just feel emotions in some scenes and I really could not wait for other episodes.


 This anime was a lot of fun and also a bit sad I have to admit, I seriously liked Rin's story and I liked a lot the fact that the productors showed us also what he really felt, it isn't something that you see in animes nowadays, since all you can see around is fanservice. About that topic (except for Gou's obsession over boy's body) it was really easy to stand, I didn't find it annoying or anything because I was more in the history, a thing that I appreciated though was that the fanservice wasn't there just for show, I mean you saw the characters(GOU GOU GOU) interract with that, it's better than seeing boobs without even a comment lol (and I like seeing boobs when it's not an useless fanservice). 


Another cute aspect of this is that everything was connected, I didn't see anything left in the hands of the case, everything was perfectly united by logic (Rei could swim with butterfly style as Rin,both Rin's father and Makoto's old friend died in the same accident, the overload of scenes were Makoto gave Haru an hand or all the time he noticed the changes on his humor or just when he spoke his thoughts) that is just amazing to me cause it's like not leaving something for guarantee , as Rei's jealousy. It would be really really stupid do not touch this topic, I mean it's so obvious that if you enter in a new gruop and this group has already a close bond you feel out of this group right? Well, I thought they were not going to show it and they proved me wrong, I was like "they cannot show this side too! That's so amazing" I loved it, really. As I loved the fact that Rin felt replaced (though it's not said you can see it, c'mon) So to me this anime touched so many themes that i hurts.


The ending was pretty good, I just didn't like the fact that Rei didn't join to them to the relay race .__. but I loved the fact that Rin stayed in his school and understood that he has to live for his own dream.

It wasn't a masterpiece but totally a good anime and I would lose a lot if I would not watch if just for my initial thoughts.


The only thing I didn't like (without counting Gou's obsession/ though I liked her as character) was the ending. It was simply disgusting.

Take Free! for what it is, a fan service sports anime, and you will not be disappointed. 
 This isn't to say that men can't enjoy this show, but just don't expect it to be something it's not. It's a sports show aimed at a female audience. Instead of the sports matches being dynamic and action packed, they are visually stunning to watch. The sports scenes have amazing artistic detail and flow, coupled with the realistic water sound effects and dramatic music (to enhance the emotions of a scene).  I re-watched this purely for how breathtakingly beautiful the art is. 
The main story isnothing to write home about, it's simple male competitive tension with an underlying hint of sexual frustration. What drives this anime is the emotional aspect; a lot of the story is told through loaded gestures and the hidden meaning in actions. It's friendship full of longing, anger, jealously, nostalgia, support, love, etc. The emotional aspect is what keeps an otherwise simple story, pretty interesting.


This is one anime where the music is really successful.  Because of how they set up scenes and how they pair certain soundtracks with emotionally charged incidents from the very beginning, just hearing the same music that will set up a scene is very successful in evoking emotions in the viewer.


In sports anime I feel I always have to touch on the realism of the athleticism in the show. The level in this anime is one of the most believable that I have seen. Some characters are ridiculously good yes, but it is because they competitively swam (and thus appropriately trained at a high level at proper institutions) since childhood. 


This is a sports anime that has a different take on sports anime, which is why I think it's so successful.

For a woman like me, watching an anime like this felt like eating candy. A bunch of really really good looking guys who happen to form a swimming club…that are perfect ingredients for many nosebleeds! Kyoto Animation is well known for series like Clannad, Air and Kanon. I’ve yet to see the last title, but the fanservice in these shows are mainly aimed at men. Nothing wrong with that and I loved Clannad and Air simply because they have great stories and art, but there’s nothing wrong with fanservice aimed at girls either. Up until now, I haven’t seen such series yet, except for otomegame anime, but there should be something better than that! And finally, I found something better. Much better!


In fact, I’m not into sports anime either, but after seeing the ads for Free!, I just couldn’t let this one pass by unnoticed. The art is fantastic and colorful, and the animated water was gorgeous! The character designs were great as well, making every boy look handsome as hell and seeing them in their swimmingsuits was enough to make me excited. I’m a girl after all. The soundtrack of this show was good too. I don’t like dubstep very much, but it fits the show very well, giving it this ‘cool’ feel. The opening from OLDCODEX is one of my favorites this season.


Aside from good appearances, I found the story pretty good as well. Free! is about Haru who loves water so much that he wants to jump in it as soon as he sees it. Together with three childhood friends they formed a swimming club when they were in elementary school. Everything changed when one of them, Rin moved to Australia to follow his deceased father’s dream to become an Olympic swimmer. The swimming club falls apart, since Haru stopped swimming and all of them went to different schools. When Haru enters high school Nagisa and Makoto happen to be in the same school and they persuade him to reestablish the old swimming club of Iwatobi Highschool. One day, they meet Rin but find out he’s changed greatly. The story about friendship isn’t new, but the show told it really well with lighthearted, funny moments but also intense scenes during the swimming tournaments and confrontations with Rin.


Surprisingly, the handsome boys seemed quite natural to me. Their emotions and feelings towards eachother were portrayed really well and especially the character development of Haru and Rin is worth pointing out. Haru started of as a bit cold and quiet boy, but as the show progressed he seemed to become more open and talked more. Only in the end Rin’s breakdown seemed a bit too expected and too sudden. There were some moments that felt a bit BL-ish and could be easily misunderstood for that, but isn’t it just true friendship? You want to be with your closest friends too, right? And hug your great teammates when you reach the first place?


Overall, I found this a really entertaining show. It’s easy to say as a girl to whom this series is aimed at, but in the end I actually loved it. On that point dear KyoAni succeeded. But I’m not so shallow minded as it seems. Good looks are important, but if I found this series boring or the story was really bad, I wouldn’t enjoy this as much as I did.


Free! is a great show for girls (and maybe boys too?) who want to look at some handsome men, and in the mean time enjoy a good story too. The story is not great and pretty simple, but enjoyable. If you expected KyoAni to make anime just for men and are ticked off because this is aimed ad girls, you might be really disappointed. But then again; appearances are not the most important thing. If you enjoyed the story, then it’s not important to who it’s aimed at!

This anime about swimming with homoerotic undertones is aight, I guess.
I guess I should write a bit more about it, the animation is great, if that's your thing you really oughta check it out. As far as the rest goes it's slightly above average. Some nice friendship moments and stuff, but as I said in the beginning, it's aight.
Appearantly that's not long enough for MAL so I'll continue, the anime is about swimming, there are swimmers in the anime and they do a lot of swimming. And then they enter some tournaments where they also swim.

People generally attracted to males will probs enjoy this, thus I rated it a 7.  


And that's my amateur review of this shitake mushroom

I found Free to be a surprisingly fascinating watch - whether it be because of the lush animation, or the characters themselves, the ultimate result was an enjoyable anime that really managed to capture my attention.
Starting with the art direction, most the scenes in Free! are a pleasure to look at - this is down to the beautiful animation which builds on a clean palette of colours to create a sleek effect that runs throughout the show. As many people have noticed, the way water is animated in the program really stands out as something special. There's a sense of depth to it that I'dimagine is very difficult to produce. In addition to this, the characters themselves are well designed, their movements fluid and their images well defined. Personally, I feel that some shows fall into the trap of making their characters look a little too similar. Here, there's no such problem. The five boys that make up the principle cast do borderline on being colour-coded, which does almost add up to being a little too obvious, but they manage to pull back from the brink. Praise should also go to the design of the women in the show - Gou especially, who is almost our, the viewer's, avatar in the world of Free! Nothing in particularly stands out in her design as something great, but I find that there's something pleasing about her look.


The soundtrack was okay, but I ultimately feel that it was nothing to write home about. It's never something that really stands out to me, which I guess to some might be a good thing in that it never feels intrusive. It complements what's going on plot-wise and scenery-wise well, so it's hard to knock it as being bad. 


Plot-wise, the show has one clear goal in mind from the outset, and it generally stick with this theme throughout the series. What I personally love so much about the story is how character driven it is. Considering this could be seen as a sports anime, where often the main goal is simply to win a trophy, the goals here seem to be much more driven by the characters' relationships with each other. Often in anime, men's bonds aren't really discussed in the way they are here. Some see this as borderline yaoi bait (there are a lot of pretty healthy shipping communities in the Free! fandom) but I find it refreshing to see a group of adolescent boys talking so openly about their feelings. So many anime go for the angst ridden young male that they almost seem to forget there are others as well (of course there is a character in the show who does follow that stereotype, but I felt that Rin, along with Nagisa, who plays the naive role, to be the weakest character.). As you can probably guess by my username there is one character who really stood out in my book - Makoto Tachibana. I found that his personality so wonderfully permeated all the scenes he took part in, which was wonderful to see. There was a strong sense of character development there which I loved. 


Overall, Free! is in my book, an underrated anime. Too many people are willing to write it off as 'that swimming anime with the scantily clad men', but ultimately, the tale it tells is a heartwarming one of friendship and honesty. I highly recommend you check it out.

Free! Iwatobi Swim Club is the first anime that I watched the full series of. Therefore, going into this I was a bit skeptical. Would I really like anime? Why was there so much hype over this? Would my love of swimming be able to save me from the vortex of the Free!dom? Was the ED song even possible to play on the piano? 
To my surprise, I ended up enjoying this quite a bit. It's probably not the anime that most people would agree should be a first anime to watch, but that's what I ended up doing. 
[ This is the first reviewI've ever written, so I don't know if this is good or not... ]


Story :: 8

To an outsider ( i.e. me, the anime noob ), Free! looked like something about an excess of muscles and very beautifully animated water. I wasn't expecting much of a plot because everyone who had seen it already could only talk about the muscles. However, fear not, there is a plot in behind all the fanservice, and it's not a unique one, but it's nevertheless interesting. I found myself earnestly anticipating what would happen in each episode. 


Art :: 9

Ah, the main focus of most people would most certainly be the art in this anime. Fanservice aside, everything was wonderfully drawn and it most certainly raised my standards for art in anime that I watched in the future! I can't give this a 10, though, because while the character designs are attractive, now that I've watched more anime, I find that they aren't extraordinarily unique. But I suppose that's to be expected. This isn't a science fiction or fantasy anime, after all. The one thing that bothered me on occasion is that the side profiles of the people can look a bit strange sometimes, but it didn't really stand out.


Sound :: 9

I had an unhealthy obsession with the ED, Splash Free, probably because I was trying to play it on the piano and the sheet music I had required some work because of the octave-jumping, and I spent a long time trying to learn them. The OP and ED are both very catchy, the background music sets a nice ambiance [ though it can be lost and unnoticed much of the time ], and the character songs are wonderful. 


Character :: 8

This anime did a good job of introducing me to the basic character tropes of anime- megane, tsundere, shota, whatever you use to refer to them- and I liked the personalities of all the characters. I do think that their personalities could have been given more facets, however, which would have made for a much more interesting story. 


Enjoyment :: 9 

Free! Iwatobi Swim Club is kind of my guilty anime pleasure now. It's not my favourite anime, but it's possibly the one that I follow and talk about the most because it's so popular and well-known. 


Overall :: 9

Free! is not the best anime out there. However, I found myself enjoying it quite a bit [ and somewhat jealous of the swimming. Why isn't my butterfly beautiful? ] and it appealed to me in many ways. Oh, and I did accomplish playing the ED ;) all's well that ends well.

I liked how fluent and beautiful animation was and how the characters facial expressions were done. I loved the characters eyes.
What I disliked was the character development of everyone except Rei's because it seemed to me like the 3 main characters developed before the show is set. And as for the red head it doesn't really explain why he became so bastardy really...
However, with the story I couldn't help but think "this has got to be more than bromances." And found myself saying "They are so gay for each other" more than once per episode. On a side note I have nothing against homosexuals orlesbians.

"Okay okay, this anime is for fujoshi ONLY. so boring"
This word was from my one of the male friend who loves Kyoto animation studio.
Some months later,
"Oh my gosh I misunderstood Free! so much and the Kyoto animation didn't betray me anymore!!! Love it!!"
Someone thinks same as it possibly.
But when I think similar view as it in advance, anyway please watch 3 episode.
This story is about high school students who loves swimming for team try to go up to the top in swimming world.
These opening song and ending ones are cool as well as character ones too.

First of all, straight guy here. Second of all, this anime is actually pretty good.
Story - 7
The story follows 3 high schoolers who were child hood friends establishing a swim club. There's so much fanservice here that it is painfully obvious that men aren't the real target audience. But still it has a cohesive plot. The characters are interesting but most look like side characters just to fill the story. It also hasn't made much layout for the background story of each character. Although it failed my expectation of it at least sizing up to [i]Haikyuu![/i] it's still watchable and I might just start thesecond season soon.


Art - 9

Now here is where 90% of the staff probably focused. The art is amazing. Very clean and very sharp. No bad quality fast scenes that will leave a bit of bad taste, but then again the actual swimming in this anime might not even total an hour for the whole series so I can't really say much in that regard.


Sound - 7

The scores are actually nice and not boring. Not very exciting either.


Character - 8 [I'm gonna give them nicknames coz Nagisa likes nicknames and I like them too]

Haru (the Water Jet) is the main protagonist-- a guy who likes to wear is swim suit under his normal clothes. He's very fixated on his old friend Rin who went away hen they were still in elementary. He obviously has a man-crush on his friend but the anime doesn't really depict him as such.


Nagisa (the Dolphin) and Makoto (the Kingfisher) are Haru's childhood friends and are mostly side characters made to make Haru and Rin more the focus of the story (like supporting characters to enhance the main characters and be the glue to the story). Although Makoto got an episode about his background story, it was not very memorable and would be forgotten on the next episodes.


Rin (the Great White) is Haru's "rival" or friend or whatever you wanna call him. He was Haru's really really good friend in elementary but went away to train his swimming skills. He returns and disregards his old friends and acts cocky. He has the deepest character amongst them and the one with the most notable character development.


Rei (the Water Butterfly) is the newest member of the swimming club and looks up to Haru. He can only swim Butterfly and sinks when he tries other techniques. He is actually one of my favorite characters with the most admirable trait amongst the swimmers. He is smart and very athletic. He is also the bridge(a character that plays a critical role to let the story move forward but isn't a main character) of the story from around episode 3 to the end.


Enjoyment - 7

I recommend watching it if you are tired of the action animes or other generic genres. It's a nice easy going anime that has a nice pacing and has a potential to grow into a much much more exciting and enjoyable anime.

So, I cried. This is such a touching story, how could I help myself?
I'm not normally into sport-related fiction, but something about these characters and their friendship together makes Free! really special. To me, it's a very honest depiction of pride and how that can ruin friendships as well as yourself. It holds a very good lesson that connecting with other people will always be more important than being the best. 
Without getting too gushy, I really do admire the strength, diversity, and depth of the five boys we get to know in this anime. While not all of them have an extensive background topick apart, they all are extraordinary characters. The story itself was amazing, and to combine that with beautiful characters made Free! magical. \n\n
If you're a fan of Yuri!!! On Ice or other competition-based anime, such as Food Wars!, then you'll fall hard for Free! It's definitely worth your time. I imagine it will touch your hearts just as much as it touched mine.

I really enjoyed watching this anime. I think that the animation style is beautiful and the colors are vibrant. I think the way it was filmed was also very beautifully done. This anime is about a group of friends who are in a high school swim team. I am not much for sports anime but there is so much more to this story. The anime shows how it feels to be a part of a team and how friendship and inspiration can have a huge impact on your life. This group of friends are very close and they not only love swimming but they loveswimming together as a team, as friends. Yes yes I’m a girl and they are all very nice to look at,  but I think that it’s anime can hit home for even guys. I also really enjoyed the music this anime as well. Just an all around great anime and I would definitely recommended it!

Let me get this off my back first, i don't like fanservice. Fanservice is basically just there to distract the viewer with boobies or pecs and most anime have girls doing the fanservice (and there is that one guy who gets a nosebleed). Free!, on the other hand does boys instead of girls . Yeah, the fanservice can and will get a little annoying here and there but Free!(unlike most fanservice filled shows) has good character and a actual plot. Now, back the review. Pros to Kyoto Animation for making the animation and sound so beautiful and fluid( well they did create on of themost saddest anime of all time...you know what i'm talking about) I didn't really like the anime because of the random fanservice( since its a swimming anime) but i digress the anime is still cool in its own ways.

Free! was alright. I actually think the idea of the story was great but it wasn't expressed that well in my opinion. 
The art was amazing! This was one of the reasons I started watching it. I saw the art style while I was browsing some anime so I checked it out. 
The characters were okay but they barely met my expectations. There wasn't enough character development based on what all of them had gone through.
The fan service...well, this was a problem. It took so much away from the anime and really made me upset. It would've easily been a wonderful anime that almost everyoneloved if it weren't for the fan service. \n\n
I gave this an overall 6 because the only big problem I had was the overly excessive fan service.

This show is definitely made for those people who desire to renew friendships, for those who keep special memories in their hearts for others, for those who believe that a great part of their past can be restored in some way. It was the same for me, which hit me straight in my heart. This show, which my friend introduced to me, always made me think of her. I wondered why for so long, and it didn't hit me until the end--it was a story about us. This is so easily relatable for those of you in need of your old friend. This story tellsyou that there is a chance of that return, and it's almost ironic that reality doesn't bet on it whereas fiction does. This one definitely shows you what that happy ending will look like and what you can do to get there, whether you are a Haru or a Rin. It is beautiful, and anyone who relates to it this strongly will cry--probably for joy (and I did, considering that my friend is now back in my life and is more like a sister than ever before).

Free! is the second sports anime that I've actually decided to sit through. Yowamushi Pedal being the first sports anime that I've actually liked, and it's following Yowamushi Pedal: Grande Road (which I'm still viewing). My enjoyment of Yowamushi Pedal was due to the attention to character development, and the obvious love for road racing by all the information giving about the spot. 
Free does not spend that type of time explaining the sport. It's all kept to a minimum only explaining about the different swimming styles and strokes. Nope, the true attention to details is spent on the muscles of the swimmers. This isfanservice for the ladies. And I enjoyed that sparkling flowers and over the top body scanning scenes weren't used. Most of the time. Instead we get to see them on display through swimming, stretching, and working out. So it felt a little more natural. Which I appreciate. It's true I watched for the fanservice. 


The characters were all stereotypical, but I do appreciate that the writing attempts to flesh them out. I won't claim it's great, but enough that I could tell them apart from their other stereotype partners. 


The story basically evolves around why the swimmers swim and the mystery to what happened to Rin and Haruka. Not to mention the meaning of swimming free. For swimming for the team and not for selfish reasons. So there was that attempt. 


If you want super Yaoi it's actually really tame. There's some veiled meaning behind water metaphors and such. As someone who is not Yoai fan I did enjoy it. AND I secretly want the next season to go there. Especially with things between Rin and Haruka. These to guys have serious chemistry. Many others do together, but Rin and Haruka are amazing to watch together. 


To be honest though the writing and plot is all at a bare minimum. So while I enjoyed myself I know I'll never come back for a reviewing. There wasn't much there to require that. This is fanservice. From guys wearing swim trunks under their close to strip at a moment. The overly dramatic swim scenes where their breathing underwater and spanning the sexy bodies. Yeah. Fanservice. Not only that but I felt like the one really interesting character gets benched and underappreciated by his new friends. Here's to next season delivering more character development. 


In the end this one is for those who like to look at the male form. You don't have to feel to guilty because there is some attempt to make it's man candy have personalities. The story is engaging enough that I genuinely wanted to know what happened in the past, and see these characters pull through to the future. Though I am happy it's streaming on Crunchyroll. This isn't one that I'd actually add to my collection, or rewatch in the future.

Free! is the continuing story of four friends who are joined by just two things: their love of swimming, and their status as "boys who have girly names," following the events of the light novel High☆Speed! That said, reading the High☆Speed! is absolutely not essential to understanding and appreciating Free!, though it may add to the experience; I, personally, enjoyed the series just fine without it, though I don't doubt I'll read the novel in the future.
Story: 8/10
As previous reviews have already stated, the plot is not the strongest point of the show- four boys reunited by chance get back into their old hobby ofswimming- however, this is a story driven more by characters than plot, anyway. While Free! might not fit in nicely with other sports anime, where the sport is always on the forefront of each character's mind, in Free! swimming is merely a vehicle to serve the story's main purpose: main character Haruka's emotional growth throughout the series. The series demonstrates Haruka's social and emotional withdrawal in the beginning of the series, then uses his involvement in the swim team to help him reconnect to the world. Often, however, the show will divert from even that plot to give fanservice moments and cute antics, which gives it an 8/10.


Art: 10/10


Easily one of the highest points of Free!, the show is absolutely beautifully drawn and animated. The visuals are clear and appealing, the colors pop pleasantly; all in all, the art is amazing.


Sound: 9/10


The sound for this series was also great. Though the opening theme might not seem to fit, it does work nicely with the rest of the sounds, which featured a wide range of styles from "muffled rap music in the distance" to "was that dubstep I just heard?" to the stereotypically cute town melody. It's not often I even recognize sound in anime, but watching the series, it does add to the overall enjoyment of the series. The end theme, sung by the main five voice actors, was cute and tied the show up nicely.


Character: 9/10


It's true: the characters are somewhat typical. I would, however, counter that with their overall likability. They play off each other nicely, and it's easy to tell the series really revolves around them and their emotional connections to each other. It's because of their interactions that I give them 9/10; if they didn't work together nearly as well, I'd rate them 8 or even 7/10 for being, frankly, a bit flat. As they play off each other, though, they drive each other-and the plot- forward, and are, again, fun to watch.


Enjoyment: 10/10


I've said this many times already, but Free! is just an enjoyable show. It's not a dark psychological analysis of the human condition, or an epic journey across time and space; it's just a few guys who like swimming and hanging out with their buds. Plain and simple. They swim, they make jokes, they get up to some wacky hijinks; there's the show. And it's absolute fun, especially when the series was running concurrent to such a dark show as Attack on Titan. It's a breath of fresh air from all the "darker and edgier" nonsense that's been going on. Just absolute fun.


Overall, I give the series a 9/10 in review; however, I feel it deserves a high 9, for whatever that's worth. If you're expecting something deep and meaningful, you'll have to work to find it in Free!- but if you're looking to watch a short series and relax, Free! is second to none.

I don't know about you guys, but what brought me to this anime was that youtube promo (you know, back when it was called "swimming anime" and had an epic sound track?). I must confess, I was incredibly anticipating this anime. I mean come on, I'm a girl, I've got my bishie-needs. Safe to say. The anime was no let down. 
The story is a bit stereotypical of sport animes. I'm giving it a 7. Very simplistic. A guy who loves his sport, has a rival, your typical used-to-be-friends-but-after-some-major-event-we-hate-each-other. However, whats wrong with stereotypes right? This anime has a rather engaging plot. It kept meseated for a good few hours. Classics are sometimes the best. 


The art is rather stunning, if I may say so myself. It has originality, its own style. It's not grandma-safe, but then again, if you are drawn to this anime, you wouldn't be the grandma kind anyway. Not to mention, the guys in swimsuits don't leave much to the imagination (And here I was beginning to think that only guys got the butt in bikinis fanservice). But yes, as we all had guessed, this anime has a lot of wet pecs and triceps on display, not that too many of us are complaining. The art deserves a 9.


Music is not the kind that causes your inner musician to awaken and inspire you to pick up your dusty violin to play crappy internet downloaded sheet music in the desperate attempt to recreate the awe-inspiring sound. But no, there is no cringe and you don't feel the soul-deep itch to skip the intro. But, then again, I kinda expected more from the music, considering how the promo I mentioned earlier has sound that is still in my head 5 months after I watched it.


The characters are stereotypical; the rival with anger management issues, the guy nest door best friend, the cutie who looks like a grade schooler, the glasses-interlect, the tsundere main yeah yeah. It's what we know and love. But one thing that has compelled me to give this an 8 is the fact that all the characters are somehow relate-able. The antagonist is not the kind that uses underhanded tricks to pull down the protagonist. They are honorable and compete fairly. That is rare in an anime that includes competition, producers seem to think that we love to see the antagonist use dirty tricks, only to lose.


The characters also have a strong sense of team spirit and group loyalty. its what we expect in a sports anime, but nice all the same. They each do a bit of individual soul searching, and thankfully, they do come to a satisfying conclusion.


The anime is certainly very enjoyable. Great characters, pretty art, compelling slice of life, perfect for a lazy afternoon. So long as your intention is not to NIT PICK the anime apart and look into the "DEEP MEANINGS" and "social implications" of the depiction of young peoples or what ever, you will find this anime enjoyable. Just don't go all English-analysis-mode. 


And of course, I think its worth mentioning, this anime teeters on the edge of being shounen-ai. I seriously doubt these boys are heterosexual. There's just some kind of sexual tension that underlies this anime. I don't know. If the anime is a BL, like Junjou, then you don't get this strange nervousness when watching it. But free! is supposed to be slice of life. Hard to explain, but this anime is certainly going to inspire some squeals from yaoi fain girls. 


Free! is an interesting anime that is worth watching, the key is not to walk into it with all your hate for fanservice and sexual undertones. After all, we are here for enjoyment, not for tearing our beloved anime apart and criticizing every piece.

If you want a fun, youthful anime then I recommend Free!
Story 7
I found myself smiling at all the little quirks and characters - overall it's a simple yet sweet story line. 
Art 8
Beautiful animation, and really depicts water movement and the emotion within characters.
Sound 8
I think the music and effects chosen were perfect. They added an element of fun whilst highlighting the idea of determination
Character 7 
The characters are easily lovable and relatable to any viewer. The relationships and interests between characters also served impact.
Overall 8
Overall, Free! is quite an average anime in itself. But the memories they evoke really take you back to teenageyears. It was a pleasure to watch this anime.\n\n\n\n\n

[DOES NOT CONTAIN ANY SPOILERS]
I have never watched any sports anime before but I heard a lot about this particular anime and decided to give it a shot. I have nothing but my time to lose, so why the hell not? I am pretty good at that already.
After the first episode I was not impressed at all and dropped this anime because characters were very poor and plot was nothing but a big nuisance. Nothing made any sense, all I saw was some gay looking guys with poor, unoriginal personalities. But when I finally decided to get back to Free!, I finished it in acouple of days. Don't get me wrong, I still was not enjoying it that much, actually, I was just looking for some plot and common sense in this gay anime (I like yaoi, so maybe that gayish atmosphere kept me there).


I could not go with this anime just because of one particular character - Rin Matsuoka. I could not believe how anyone could be so stupid and arrogant to fuck up a nice friendship and it just had to take another innocent character to put everyone in their minds and give some common sense. That is the most unoriginal thing someone could come up with. I still don't understand why Rin had to do they way he did, though everthing was finally explained in some twisted logic (is logic a good word here?). 


Though Free! has poor protagonists, the art is really nice and eye-catching. I really enjoyed animation and sound quality. I cannot say anything bad about it (muscles are really pretty nice, girls c;).


In overall, people who love sports anime will definitely love this one too but the ones who like philosophy, logic and fine reasoning won't be satisfied with plost and whole storyline at all.

Okay, if Free! really was "just" fanservice, you know what would happen? The guys would have sex ALL THE TIME. It'd just be that: 22 minutes of hot male on male action.
And, NO, Free! isn't that at all! While that would be awesome as well, Free! is mostly focused on friendships, teamwork, the meaning of water/swimming and finding your place in the universe (in some cases).
And it's so satisfying that, even if there's not even ONE KISS between any of the couples, you can't help but enjoy it all the same. Because these boys are enjoyable as hell!
I just rewatched the first season and damn,I love this anime even more than the first time around! These boys have a special place in my heart <3

This is an anime that seems to be full of homosexual innuendo. 
You are shown a bunch of kids in a swimming club with FEMALE voice actors playing their childhood voices, and one trait they share in common is that all of them have FEMALE like names.
This anime is a bromance? which almost steps over and becomes a homosexual anime but doesn't, and keeps itself to be alllll about swimming but you get some uncomfortable scenes (speaking as a heterosexual person) from time to time. There's a perverted girl that has an obsession to muscles.
This anime was pretty funny, if I ignore the stuff thatmakes me uncomfortable, then this is a pretty good anime. Obviously, this anime is catered more to females, it's more like a shoujo Boy's Love anime more than a sports anime (which I thought was about swimming), but nevertheless it was good. \n\n
There's quite a fair amount of comedy, lots of crying (the characters), and I suppose, touching moments (can't say I felt anything during the tear jerking feels portion of the anime). The art is nice, I liked the sound, but the story was a bit mediocre. \n\n
Overall, if you don't mind watching a slightly homosexual anime, and you're comfortable watching masculine males getting close together, all huggy buddy and bubbly together, then this might be a good anime to watch.

I was fairly interested in watching Free! when I first knew of its existence. The series was yet to start and I noticed that it was garnering a lot of attention. When I saw a group visual for the anime, I immediately knew why, but I wasn't in it for the topless guys splashing around a pool full of other topless guys (okay, maybe a bit hihi). I enjoy sports anime very much so I was really in it for the tournaments and other stuff that comes along with it. 
Story - 7/10 
When I found out that the series was only 12 episodes long,I got a bit skeptical. I noticed how sports anime usually lasts at least 25 episodes per series so I had a hunch that the quality of the story (or how they convey it) would be quite compromised. 


The story was, okay. It went at a fair pace, although there were times when I thought "Well, that escalated quickly." but they were rare times and could easily be overlooked. There were moments where the story becomes a little bit predictable, but maybe that's just because I'm someone who unconsciously likes to predict possible outcomes of this and that. 


Although everything was about swimming, unlike other sports anime, Free! didn't revolve much around the dynamics and technicalities of the sport. Rather, the series was leaning more to how swimming affected the main character (Haru) and the people around him.


Art and Animation - 10/10

HECK YES. The art is probably one of the major reasons why I wanted to watch the series. Free! was visually stunning, and no, not just because of the well carved torsos or the impeccably perfect triceps, but because of the well carved torsos and the impeccably perfect triceps. Haha! But seriously, it wasn't because they were hot as summer whenever they appear sans their shirts, it's because of how well they were portrayed sans their shirts. The detail is no joke, people. And the way they animated them moving through difficult-to-animate water was just STUNNING. 


And yes, they do wear clothes other than their swimsuits and uniforms. Another factor that I really like about the art is how each character is does not have one full closet of the same casual clothing. Provided that the times that they do wear casual clothing is less than when they're shirtless or in their school uniform, all the more that I appreciate the effort exerted in making their clothes vary and fashionable. 


I can't even properly put to words how amazing the art (and animation) is for Free! but if you want to check it out without really spoiling yourself, you can go and search videos of the Opening and Ending clips of the series.


Sound - 9/10

And speaking of the OP and ED of the series, both were enjoyable and can really get you hooked. The opening song is sang by Oldcodex, and having watched Kuroko no Basuke, I didn't have to worry about whether I was going to like the opening song or not. It was upbeat and listening to it coupled with the animation would really get you hyped up. Whenever I watch and/or listen to it I would unknowingly feel my breath hitch for a second or two. You know how songs could reach out to you in a certain way whenever you hear it? Being a music lover, songs that make me hold my breath while building excitement are the best! 


But while I liked the opening song, the ending song is what got me sold! The concept was very unique. It was different and entertaining to watch. The music was perfect in every way that it can be. I adore the song so much that I have it on repeat right this moment (LSS right here guys, save me) and I probably won't be able to get it out of my head for the rest of the week. 


The soundtrack in the anime were okay. It doesn't stand out greatly, but that doesn't matter much since mostly don't even notice that a soundtrack is playing. However I do take notice of the background music of scenes, whether they're appropriate or not, and for Free!, well, it was again, okay. 


Character - 8/10

As I've mentioned above, Free! doesn't dwell on the technicalities and dynamics of swimming but more on how the sport influences the main character and the people around him. This means that unlike in other sports anime, character development in Free! isn't only limited to one's growth his/her skills and attitude towards the sport and the competition. Truth be told, there is little to no development with their swimming skills other than their increasing stamina and other basic aspects. 


The characters are the focal point of the series. Their attitude towards each other was highlighted throughout the twelve episodes and it was pretty interesting to watch for a change. Although it is implied in the first few episodes how there's some deep history between Haru and Rin, later on you'll discover how it wasn't that deep really, but also not too shallow. The characters still had substance and albeit somewhat lacking in a way (probably because of how short the series was), were still fairly interesting.


Enjoyment - 8/10

What girl wouldn't enjoy seeing half-naked boys splashing about with more half-naked boys, right? Lol, that sounded so wrong, but hey, the series was still pretty entertaining to watch. I was a little bit let down when I discovered how the series wasn't geared much to the sport itself, but I still ended up wanting to watch it till the end. 


There are a lot of cringe-worthy moments and yes I'm pertaining to the fanservice moments of the series. It was disturbing but not to the extent that I had to pause the episode to take a breather and compose myself. I'm an expert in ignoring fanservice as the series progresses so it wasn't much of a problem for me.


I was skeptical at first, but in the end it was enjoying; not one of the greats, but still entertaining.


Overall - 8/10

If you're looking for a sports anime that's toned down in terms of tournaments and competitive rivalry, then I'd suggest you check out Free! Although the story was a little lacking, it doesn't really matter much once you actually watch it. Not bad, so I say.

Okayokay, don't expect to take this anime seriously at first. I don't care who you are, if you can easily find the humor in things, you'll enjoy it. However, things do begin to get kind of serious half way through. It is the typical, 'We'll string you along with humor and then gut you like a fish with emotions'. 
Also, if you do enjoy both seasons of the original, I recommend watching the parody on YouTube '50% Off'. It's hilarious.
And there are also the shipping, bromances  and damn fine body pillows that come with liking the show, I mean who doesn't love that? (Ifyou say you don't then you're a filthy liar).

NO SPOILERS!
Characters 8\10
I would first love to talk about fanservice:
Free! is highly criticized because of the fanservice, but I don't understand why.
The characters are hot. Yes this is true. They have muscles, but in no way did I feel that they had no personality. Let's start with Haru:
Haru is antisocial and a quirky guy whose only concern is swimming. He doesn't enjoy doing things that take too much effort.
He likes to do as he pleases. At first glance it doesn't seem like it, but he does in fact cares about his friends. I would like to discuss his character more but it will be filledwith spoilers. You might feel like he got it all figured out, but actually, he is not so sure anymore, which makes him very confused.


Rin: more about him in second season, too. Anyway, he moved to Australia to learn swimming professionally, only to come back four years later. He changed, he is not this cheerful and bold as he was as a kid and he is aggressive and brutal. We later discover why he changed and turned out to be like this and we do feel it is only natural for him to feel that way.


Nagisa: He seems harmless at first glance, but he actually would go very far into getting what he wants. He can be annoying at times and manipulative, but he does have good intentions and he deeply cares for his friends.


Makoto: oooh where should i start? He is a goodhearted kid who cares deeply for his friends and always takes care of Haru.

He is able to be manipulative but he doesn't really have bad intentions. He doesn't mind showing his fears. He cares deeply for Haru and he gets worried about him easily. He sacrifices for his friend.


Rei: You think he is a brutal and clever guy. He is very clever when it comes to logic and he is a genius when it comes to calculating things, but it seems that he can be easily manipulated. He is not stupid, he is simply naive. He doesn't like anything that isn't beautiful.


Nitori: He is a sweetheart. He seems to care for Rin, but he isn't able to figure him out. He lacks self confidence, but he can be determined. More about him in the second season.

This is it for the main characters.


Art: 10\10

The art was beautiful. I am not simply talking about the characters; the water. Do you know how hard it is to draw water and make it believable? Also, the character design was really good; their bodies fit perfectly with the type of strokes they do. Also, their expressions were very believable and made you understand what they were thinking.


Sound: 8\10:

The voice actors were really good! They were able to convey the emotions of the characters. I thought that the music was good as well to set the mood, but sometimes I felt like it didn't always need to have a background music.


Story: 8\10

The story was enjoyable and cute and the plot was well written. It is simple and not too complicated, but the reason why i thought it was very good was because of how well it went with the characters and I believe that, with their personalities, their ways of acting were very believable. 


Enjoyment: 10\10:

There was never a moment where I was bored, I laughed my ass off a lot and at the same time I felt so sad and was left with SO many feels. The last episode, I was laughing and punching a pillow and I had so many feels!!! It got even better in the second season.


Overall: 9\10

Its simple plot and believable characters were mixed with appealing arts and beautiful sounds, and mixing drama and comedy, the anime was in the end very good and I can say that it motivated me to do few things I have been delaying, after watching them working hard and triumphing.



I highly recommend this anime. Heck, this anime is the reason why I watched 10 other anime just to shake off this empty feeling after it all ended!

High school boys in swimsuits, what more can you ask for?
Free is no doubt different from others from the sports genre, why you ask
Well it has to do with swimming and it caters to the female audience in terms of animation but other than that its follows the same story structure.
Free isn’t as intense as most sports anime like Hajime no Ippo or Kuroko no basket, reason for this is most likely due to it only being 12 episodes. As I said before Free follows the basic sport genre structure, that being; you meet the main character Haruka Nanase, he trains for competition then hecompetes in said competition.  Additionally the story involves flashbacks , member recruiting, character development and understanding parts as well as the good ol comic relief segments that end up progressing the story.

In terms of pacing, Free has done quite well as nothing feels rush and flows nicely like a stream


Art:

Why does he have shark teeth? 

The character design in free is really good as the characters look quite good in terms of colour and structure. All the male characters have a tone lean build, which is accompanied by epic abdominals that only appear in competition. The water is a high point to the art, as it simply looks beautiful.

The Scenery is also done pretty good and it will catch your eye.


Characters:

The characters are likable and different from each other which makes free a lot more enjoyable.


You have Haruka the stone cold, emotionless one with a fetish for water

Makoto, a father like character with a kind and caring nature

Nagisa, the more girly type of guy, whose sociable and easy going

Rei; the guy who thinks everything can be explained and accomplished with theory

Shark boy: a competitive, arrogant P***k with a obsession in beating haruka which he secretly loves(Opinionated)

there also few others such as Shark boy sister Gou. 


Sound:

The OP was really good it looked good(except for the rape scene) and sounded awesome, the ED not so much as it failed in every way

Soundtrack/background noise was done well and was timed really well, making it that much more enjoyable.

The voice actors have done a good job and they match their characters. My only qualm with the sound is for the silver hair chap who has the most irritating voice and personality in short he’s worse than the ED.


Free is a good watch that will leave you satisfied. It can get a bit homo at times but other than that it’s a decent sport anime.

Everyone wants to be free. The definition of free is different for everybody though. Well for Haruka Being free means being in the water and you’re about to discover what Free! means for me. ^^
Well to be honest I am quite disappointed in Free!. Why? Because I started watching it as recommendation from Kuroko no Basket. Well lets make one thing clear Free! isn’t about sports at all. It is more about friendship and slice of life. “How can you make swimming exciting?” was my first question when I started this serie. Waiting for to be blown off my chair I started this serie. UnfortunatelyI didn’t even felt a breeze and my chair just stayed upright. But after watching the first 8 episodes I realized that the serie doesn’t rely on that at all. From then the serie became much better for me. I found this serie fairly enjoyable, what means I don’t regret watching it. But on the other side I won’t recommend this serie to anyone.


Now all this is known, I guess I can start the review properly now. Well the story is about a group of guys (With girl names) that like to swim. At first they seem to have a weird bond. It is later on that you see how big and natural it actually is. I don’t think you need to know much more since the strength of it isn’t the story.


What I really liked about the series are the characters. Especially Haruka and Rin, who are old teammates/friends but eventually became rivals because of some circumstances. Well the rival story isn’t completely true. Rin takes Haruka as his rival, but Haruka doesn’t feel like taking swimming competitively serious. He just loves to be be in the water. It lets him feel free. So I’m convinced that “swimming is his passion” would be an understatement for Haruka. Swimming is more like breathing for him. The way he stays so mysterious while you experience his thoughts is very good! The same counts for Rin, the characters does have something special in the beginning. But they become very good at the end. It is a bit like a sunflower that is growing. You know that it has the potential to become something so beautiful what already makes it kinda beautiful. But once they started to blossom they become extremely beautiful!


The art is gorgeous and surely played an important role for all those female fans. The swimming scenes are so beautiful and the character looks very good to. The style of drawing fits the story perfectly! The OST isn’t special at all, they have a good opening though. And the voice acting is also good. Enjoyment was something that lacks in my opinion. This has probably only worsen because of my wrong expectations. I really liked the end though and I am curious what season 2 will bring. ^^

I have to say, this is one of the best anime I have ever watched. I know, a lot of comments say ‘fan service’, but I have to disagree. Now, I know there are different opinions than mine, I’m not saying mine is the best or theirs should be invalidated, but I will say all these people who fail to realize that others have opinions and won’t always agree on things with them should not be allowed to call this show ‘shit’. 
First, I can understand how some may see this as fan service, though I have to say that isn’t all the show is.Yes, there is some in there, I cannot deny that, but it is not purely a ‘show for girls to fan over’. The show is not meant to be too in depth but the plot is one that will leave you thinking. The theme of this show is friendship and growing up, as you watch it you follow Haruka Nanase and the rest of the Iwatobi gang as they bond over their love for swimming and try to reconnect with an old friend, Rin Matsuoka. 


So, first, let me get this out of the way: Swimming guys are going to be half naked. That in no way can be called fan service. Yes, maybe they didn’t need those prolonged scenes of Haruka getting out of his tub (He has jammers on so calm down anyone who thinks otherwise), but they’re going to be shirtless, they’re going to have muscles. Another thing to point out is the fact that the characters are close, everything they do can be interpreted as you like, so that means you can see it as friendship or as pure yaoi. Again, it’s up to you. In no way does that mean that this is fan service, it’s all up to interpretation.


Next, I would like to say that the characters did develop during the show, it wasn’t some great life changing development, it was rather more realistic which may be why so many people have a problem with it. Haruka Nanase begins to appreciate his friends more, learning they are all he needs to swim freely, and he also realizes he needs to leave behind his bad memories in order to move forward. Rin Matsuoka learns to let go of his past, instead embracing a warmer future where he can swim happily and reconnect with his old friends. The gang learns teamwork and all become closer during the show, with there being both ups and downs in their friendships. Fears are explored, acceptance is given, and the characters all grow as they learn new values and morals to live by. It is subtle but still there, still present as it would be in our lives. We don’t rapidly change over the course of a couple months, it is a gradual process, so in this way you can see the show is even more realistic.


If you don’t agree with me, that is fine, but please do not be the asshole who writes that it shouldn’t have the score it has. Do not put women under the bus stating that this isn’t fair because men can’t have high scoring fan service anime. Especially, do not say that ‘any respectable women needs to give this a 2 or 3’. IT IS NOT FAIR TO PUSH YOUR OPINIONS ON OTHERS. Realize that while I have this opinion, the next person reading this may differ, and the person after that, that makes them no less of a person, but when you shame them and imply that they would be disrespectable if they liked this show then you should get no kindness here. Eighth Review - Free!
What do I even say about this anime? well at first I wasn't so keen to pick it up and watch. Boys in swimsuits swimming and all, not really my style. These characters where actually well designed and thought off, Haru in particular with his 'cold-like' attitude but he still loves some things (Like Mackerel!)
