I'm going to make this quick.
WATCH THIS SHOW IF:
--you like comedy and teen angst
--you like seeing shirtless boys
--you want to laugh and be at the edge of your seat
--you like dramatic swimming scenes
--you like lighthearted anime
--you easily ship characters together
DO NOT WATCH THIS SHOW IF:
--you get triggered by fanservice
--you want a deep plot and strong backstories
--you hate standard character themes (the nerd, the comic relief, etc)
--you don't like swimming or sports anime in general
If you said YES to most of the 'Watch this show if" points, then sit back with some snacks and a smile, because you're going to enjoy this show. Free is alighthearted sports anime with just enough angst and drama to keep it interesting. Stunning animation and relatable characters, paired with overwhelming fanservice, make this anime very popular with the teenage female demographic. The music is catchy, the plot is satisfying, and there's a lot of teamwork to cheer about. Overall, it's a very enjoyable show.\n\n
However, Free is not the show to watch intently, looking at plot and character development. Most of the characters fit a certain 'type'. There's the strong and silent Haru, the caring Makoto, the goofy and child-like Nagisa, the nerd Rei, and the angsty and violent Rin. Using these character tropes, it is easy to determine where the plot will go. The backstories of the characters, besides the Rin/Haru conflict, are also not fleshed out. Don't watch this anime expecting anything more than a comedic swimming drama.\n\n
Thanks for reading, hope this helped!\n\n\n\n\n\n

I went into this anime not knowing anything except that it's a show about a swim club and that it was pretty popular. Having never watched sports anime, I didn't know what to expect. After watching it, I love it.
Story (7):
The story follows a group of swimmers who were childhood friends who end up forming a swim club at their high school. They then plan to compete against other teams, and ultimately race against their old friend now rival at an opposing school.
The drama is nicely done. I quickly found myself invested in these characters and their dilemmas, both in the swim world, and intheir life outside the sport. 


There is a lot of drama, but also a good amount of comedy. There is one episode in particular where the team goes to a festival, and one character follows around two of their rivals-it is hilarious. 


One issue I do have (and I realize it's a personal pet peeve) is the excess of fan service. There is quite a bit of it in this anime, which I feel takes away from the overall story.


Also, Haruka's fascination with water does get old pretty quick.


Characters (9):


This is probably one of the few anime I've seen in which I don't dislike a single character. Every single character has their own personality and are each naturally likable and relatable. 


Makoto is incredibly sweet-the kind of person you'd want to be your best friend. Nagisa is adorable and hilarious. Rei is a great character-and it's fun to watch him transform from someone who can't swim to being an important member of the team. Rin is a good antagonist while still remaining likable.


Ironically, the only character I don't have too strong a connection to is the protagonist Haruka. I don't dislike him, but compared to the other wonderful characters he comes across as a bit bland.


The characters are what made me like this show.


Art (8):


The art is beautiful. I've never seen water so clear, so pretty, and so beautifully animated as it is in this anime. The swimming animation is also pretty to watch.


The character designs are all well done, each one stands out. 


In short, this anime is beautiful to watch.


Sound (8):


The voice acting is good. I watched a few episodes in the original audio, and a few with the English dub. I found both to be enjoyable. 


The opening song is cool. Still it is the ending theme that I love. It's one of my all time favorite anime ending songs, and even now I enjoy listening to that song by itself.


Enjoyment (8):


I was intrigued with this anime. I had a fun time watching it and would definitely watch both this one and the second season again.


Overall (8):


Free! is a fun anime to watch. It's pretty to look at and has good characters. The story is interesting. And of course, that ending song is fantastic.


8/10.

10 out of 10 for eye candy....
This was a light-hearted, simple anime, but one that had a well-developed enough story to support itself. It was humorous without being overly silly or illogical. Not a masterpiece, but I would still recommend it. There are a lot of flashbacks, so if you don't like that then maybe this isn't the anime for you.
The animation was standard to slightly above average. I appreciated that the musculature on the characters, while very well defined, was not too bulgy or unrealistic. It felt like the approprivate amount of musculature for a group of swimmers. The music, while not phenomenal, waspretty good.\n\n

From the cover photo itself, everyone can tell that Free! is most definitely not an anime for everyone. It is, in fact, an anime catered towards the female population; a rarity in the world where most shows are made for men. Put away the unexplainably perky boobs and long, long legs, boys, this fanservice is all about broad shoulders, abs and biceps.
Free! is anything but complex. It's about as basic as a slice of life anime can get. You have four boys who went to the same swimming club as children before one of them moves away and later coming back in a different swimmingteam. It's a high school comedy-drama, nothing that should make your head spin. The plot takes its time with progression, at a pace that is rather slow but not dragging. At 12 episodes there really wasn't much to be going on about and Free! makes use of it and keeps up its leisurely pace.


The characters are heavily reliant on tropes. They aren't anyone no one has ever seen before. You have the broody main character, his cheerful gentle giant of a best friend/sidekick, the mischievous ~shota~ and the very angsty frienemy who is motivated by pressure to beat the MC. Perhaps the only really memorable ones are Gou who serves as the female representation in the anime and Rei who subverts the serious megane type to show an extremely goofy side. Gou is important because she acts just like the target viewers of the show-- she's a typical fangirl, fawning over the swimmers and their bodies, shipping the boys with one another. Still, the characters didn't really feel flat, they had enough of their own motivations, quirks and fears to feel three-dimensional.


The artwork was amazing and the character design was incredible. The way it's different from other fanservice-reliant animes is that they kept the body proportions right. Comparing the main characters' bodies to actual swimmers wouldn't be ridiculous as they're more or less the same. There's also variations in their body types: long and lean are Haru, Rin and Rei; large and well-built is Makoto; and small but compact is Nagisa. On the backgrounds and other details, the artist did well. From the droplets of water on their eyelashes to the leaves of the trees, nothing seemed underdone. The animation of the boys swimming were great, their strokes flowed well and it was done smoothly, just overall excellent.


I didn't focus on the sound during watching, mainly because they seemed so natural. The opening and ending songs were great, though! The music and the video themselves were highly entertaining. The boys' characters can really be seen in it, no matter how ridiculous it all was (the way Haru was dancing so unenthusiastically and just kind of swaying around in the club while everyone was showing off their maddest dancing skills was hilarious).


It's fairly obvious that it is targeted towards female fangirls, especially those who can be considered fujoshis. The humor is silly, some of the plot progressions ridiculous but it all works well for the show. I'm not ashamed to say I find this quality entertainment.


As a conclusion, it's a very good show that managed to deliver despite its at times over-the-top premise. It overcomes possible problems with good art, relatable characters and very high rewatchability. Like I said, it's not for everyone but as part of its target audience, it did very well.

First of all let's be honest the characters are pretty attractive, but who says that is only for the female audience is wrong, they are attractive obviously because it's a swimming anime, and seriously if people think it's full of fan-service(for females) then good because we girls also deserve some, anime is full of "panty shots" and fan service for boys,we girls deserve some too. I find the anime to be extremely funny and well done in terms of animation, in the end it's not about fan service or the fact that he anime looks slightly "shounen-ai", it's about childhood friends who want to swimtogether again, and that's a nice thing, remembering the childhood days. The only things that bothered me was the whole "too much Rin centered story", it should have not been about competing against Rin but competing as a team for the win(without Rin) but it was nice to see that in the end they just ended up being friends again.\n
Can't wait for second season ^^

Story: 9- Free! revolves around the Iwatobi Swim Club (hence the title). The story begins with 4 boys who swam together in elementary school but had parted ways for one reason or another. Years later they are now in high school and reunite to start another swim club.
Art: 9- The animation and style of the show was very well done! The animation of the water and point of view from the swimmers was beautifully depicted, giving a very life like feel. The art of the actual characters was well done, of course each of the male characters was given well sculpted swimmers body.
Sound: 9- Ithought the music was well matched in each scene. Besides being well matched there was a large variety of music played throughout the sound track of the show, which helped it from feeling repetitive.


Characters: 9- All though there was only 12 episodes the writers did a wonderful job developing the personalty and back story of each character. I found the group as a whole to be comical and engaging and work well together. As the series progresses we see much emphasis placed on the bonds of friendship, a more than subtle underlying theme.


Enjoyment: 9- I highly enjoyed Free! and would recommend it. All though the genre is a bit different from what I normally watch I am very glad I gave it a chance. I am excited to see how the second season will play out as well!


Overall: 9- Overall Free! was a great series. I know it has been addressed that many people will overlook this because it 'looks gay'. However yaoi is never implied, it is merely the story of a close developing friendship between the members of the Iwatobi Swim Club.

Do you think swimming is boring? WELL I THINK YOUR ATTITUDE TOWARDS THIS ANIME IS BORING! :D
Being able to turn a relatively boring subject (at least for most of the people on this earth) into a heart-warming and enjoyable anime, just that is incredible! The story is simple and straightforward, so you get the point of the anime which of course has its good and bad sides. I like the way how the story continually does flashbacks and tells you about the past in a non-viscous way (*ERHM... Naruto *COUGH... Bleach) but instead nice and nostalgic way is really appreciated.
Since the anime is from the21st century you just got to expect great art, and this anime is a good example of that. Especially the way water is animated is really well made and detailed. A beautiful sight for your eyes with 1080p quality (^w^)


Something that I'm being picky with is the music choice for the anime. Sometimes I like it. But sometimes I hate it. I don't know whether I like it or hate it. But overall it's GOOD. The casual steel-stringed acoustic guitar fits really nice to the calm, character building scenes. But during the more dramatical scenes I miss the "exciting" music, which makes you jump out of the bed by the attraction and enchantment. 


I don't think I need to say anything about the characters. They are pretty typical for a slice of life anime. A gang of 4 people:

1. The cool guy (calm and handsome, yet the best and most skilled of them)

2. The uncle (he's the one who keeps the gang alive, the link to keeping them together)

3. The over-exalted guy (always happy, and positive, the one who makes the other shine during tough times)

4. The intellectual one (the brain! Enough said XD)


So did I experience the anime as an enjoyable type of anime? Well, I can't deny it. Some slice of life animes are really slow and protracted, but I can't say that about "Free!". I started watching it on a friday and the next day it was finished! It was just so captivating I couldn't stop. It was like one episode, and then the next one, and the next one, and the next one... OH! Wait... I finished the 12th one... :'(((((((


Lastly

if you have been wondering whether to watch this anime or not. I would say: "You won't regret it!". Why not? I think it's good enough for you to consider it as good. Maybe you give a grade as high as a 10, but it's not bad, not in anyone's eyes.

Being honest with you, I was reluctant to watch Free! I was just told it's about swimming and the art is really nice and that wasn't enough to persuade me to watch it. But when I heard a bit more about the story I said I'd watch it. And I'm glad I did. It was a really good anime
I wasn't too sure about the story at first. It reminded me of Clannad except they got things done quicker with less of an emotional journey. And less character development. The story was enjoyable but predictable. I felt like it was a bit rushed, and it neededmore episodes to carry out the story without it seeming rushed. 


The art was outstanding, the water looked incredible and the characters were drawn nicely. I loved how Rin and Haru were drawn. All the characters did look well, but Rei's glasses kind of take away from how his eyes look. Makoto's face showed how kind he is and how he's the guy who has everyone's back. Nagisa had the typical Boy Lolita look but it suits him and shows his personality. Haru's eyes showed how much he just wanted to swim and be free. Rin looked awesome, his pointy teeth are really cool and his eyes were drawn really well. He also had the facial expressions that showed he was trying to look like he didn't care, but on the inside he did. 


The characters were all really good and the main characters did develop during the series, but they needed a bit more time to develop. When I watched it I didn't see any character development at all, but thinking about it now I can see how the characters grew. Especially Rin and Haru. 

Rei was recruited for the club to fill in Rin's empty spot, but I felt like they made it too obvious that he was a substitute for Rin. He was a bit stuck up and even though he did learn how to swim it made no sense how he actually learned. He just tried one move and that's it. There's another reason why this anime needed more episodes. And it's official that Nitori is king of the Notice Me Senpai Club..


I loved the music. It fit every situation. I love the ending song, it's sung by their Japanese voice actors and it sounds awesome. (I'm actually listening to the soundtrack while writing this review) The opening song was good but it wasn't amazing. 


The is anime really needed more episodes for the characters to develop, especially Rei. I'm currently watching the second season and there has been some character development with Nagisa and Nitori.

Overall this anime is really good and I do recommend it for sports anime lovers and if you want to try something new, it's really enjoyable.

The story line was fairly good. The plot was original and sensible. 
The art was amazing. Really well done in my opinion.
The sound was a straight up 10. Voice acting = fantastic. Music = OUTSTANDING! I absolutely loved the outro song.
The characters were good. The anime had a lot of the stereo-typical personalities, but with their own twists. I really loved Makoto and Haru(naturally).
Overall I really enjoyed this. In my opinion, it kept a steady pace. Never going slow enough to be annoying; never going fast enough to be confusing or jumbley.
8/10 From me.

I have to say that I was very, very pleasantly surprised by Free! I have been consciously avoiding sports animes for quite some time now, and when a new friend on Tumblr finally convinced me to take a peak, I was hooked from the first episode. 
The story is pretty simple: former swimming teammates get together again in high school and start a new club. The character typologies are pretty stereotypical at first glance: we have the quiet guy, the nurturing one, the glasses character, and the sweet Honey-senpai-like figure who sometimes ends up being the most reasonable one. On the other side, we haveRin Matsuoka, a childhood friend and now-rival of the newly-formed Iwatobi Club. It all seems pretty basic until you get into the show and realize how well the character development has been elaborated, considering this is a sports anime.


Besides the usual comedy and drama, these characters have issues that are very relatable to anyone who has ever felt pressure from their friends, parents, teachers etc. This anime made me feel nostalgic about high school and the friends I gained there. 


The art is absolutely breathtaking, I never would have thought that it would be done with such beautiful care and precision. The same goes for the music, including the opening and ending sequences which have become sort of a meme in their own right.


Overall, I enjoyed Free! much, much more than I originally thought I would, and if anyone thinks that sports animes are not their cup of tea, maybe they should start with this one.

If you are looking for a story that WON'T get you:
1) Sobbing your eyes out
2) Grabbing your heart from anxiety
3) Hugging yourself in fear
4) Tearing at your hair in frustration
5) or a masterpiece upon which you've never laid eyes on before or after
...then "Free!" might be what you're looking for. It is no way a bad series, but it is a mellow, slice of life. There isn't blood or life-or-death scenarios, so it takes a certain type of viewer to appreciate the plot of repairing friendships and the characters.
It WILL GET YOU:
1) Lots of shirtless bishounen (pretty boys)
2) Swimming
3) Warm fuzzy feelings
PLUS, the MUSIC ISPRETTY GREAT.\n\n
RECOMMEND to those who are or were swimmers who would appreciate the sport aspect of this anime, those with tender hearts who don't need an action-packed anime that has them gripping the edges of their seats, and BL fans who like to really kick the male-male relationships up to the next level ---this series makes it easy.

Before I say anything else I feel it important to firstly state the Free! Iwatobi Swim Club was not a sports anime. How can I make this claim? Simple. There was less actual swimming taking place in this anime than there was melodrama. 
I'll use Kuroko No Basuke for a comparative example. In KNB, all of the arcs, sub-plots and drama could be drawn back to basketball. If you got rid of basketball, none of the sub-plots or character development would make sense.In Free!, you could literally replace swimming with any other sport without the plot changing in any way. Hell, you could replace theswim club with chess club and the story would still be the same. 


There were scenes in which Rin would pin Haruka to a wall/fence and yell at him. Those interactions reeked of unresolved sexual tension more than anything else, and really took you out of the scene. Which brings me to point that the amount of UST in this anime was astounding, and it will always be just UST because the writers of the show have decided not make any pairings cannon, despite the constant bedroom eyes.


That being said, there were a few things I liked about Free!. The absolutely gorgeous animation, Rei and Nagisa's interactions and Rei as a character.

Free! yeah, so I think we all know why most of us got here. Because we knew It's about guys swimming, and we all know guys swimming=biceps. So for those of you who watched it and ended up seeing my review: most of us got to Free 'cause we are Gou.
But I don't know about you, I found there is much more to it then that.
So, shall we begin with pros? Yes, we shall.
The story is very good and actually educational. Through the anime we learn about friendship and teamwork and what a team truly is. Wow. that sounds so cliche' I think I'm gonnadie. But it's not. 


The characters are amazing and each have it's own personality, weaknesses included. The anime admits that even boys like THAT have their weak sides. it's fun to follow these characters and I found myself wishing for them that everything will go well. Some characters are deep and some are funny and hyper. there is a bit of everything.


The art is good and I find it fun. well, but it isn't something that sticks out.

The music is fun and I found myself even staying for the ending theme, witch is rare.


Now for the cons.

So this might seem stupid, but I feel the need to warn. The anime is pretty misleading. I was sitting in my room, waiting for some romance, but every time there was a spark it turned out to be friendship.


And the end. It was satisfying but I expected more. a few things got in the way so it wasn't perfect. I think it could've ended better. 


My conclusion? 

Recommended for people looking for a fun and short anime. Also, highly recommended for girls looking for biceps and hot guys ;)


I tried to make it short and helpful. 

Hope it was

Free!
Review By: John Fragglepuss Evans
Free! is a sports anime that anybody can enjoy. It has a great storyline that includes comedy and a dash of drama. The characters are both lovable and unlovable, developing as the story progresses. I have never been much into the sport of swimming, but Free! had me interested in it from the beginning.
You might enjoy this if: You are looking for a coming of age, slice of life, sports anime. Free! has all the necessary elements of these genres and has put them together well.
You might not like it if: You are looking for romantic interersts as an important partof the anime. Free! truly revoloves around the friendship of these highschool boys.\n\n
Note to the Viewer: Watch for subtle jokes throughout the season, such as the mysterious background of their teacher and how all the boys have traditionally girl names.

The voice of the oil man sounds made of oil, gristle and syrup. It is deep and reassuring, absolutely sure of itself, and curiously fraudulent. No man who sounds this forthright can be other than a liar. His name is Daniel Plainview, and he must have given the name to himself as a private joke, for little that he does is as it seems. In Paul Thomas Anderson's brutal, driving epic "There Will Be Blood," he begins by trying to wrest silver from the earth with a pick and shovel, and ends by extracting countless barrels of oil whose wealth he keeps all for himself.Daniel Day-Lewis makes him a great oversize monster who hates all men, including therefore himself.


Watching the movie is like viewing a natural disaster that you cannot turn away from. By that I do not mean that the movie is bad, any more than it is good. It is a force beyond categories. It has scenes of terror and poignancy, scenes of ruthless chicanery, scenes awesome for their scope, moments echoing with whispers and an ending that in some peculiar way this material demands, because it could not conclude on an appropriate note -- there has been nothing appropriate about it. Those who hate the ending, and there may be many, might be asked to dictate a different one. Something bittersweet, perhaps? Grandly tragic? Only madness can supply a termination for this story.


The movie is very loosely based on Oil!, Upton Sinclair's 1927 novel about a corrupt oil family based so loosely, you can see the film, read the book and experience two different stories. Anderson's character is a man who has no friends, no lovers, no real partners and an adopted son that he exploits mostly as a prop. Plainview comes from nowhere, stays in contact with no one, and when a man appears claiming to be his half-brother, it is not surprising that they have never met before. Plainview's only goal in life is to become enormously wealthy, and he does so, reminding me of "Citizen Kane" and Mr. Bernstein's observation, "It's easy to make a lot of money, if that's all you want to do is make a lot of money."


"There Will Be Blood" is no "Kane" however. Plainview lacks a "Rosebud." He regrets nothing, misses nothing, pities nothing, and when he falls down a mine shaft and cruelly breaks his leg, he hauls himself back up to the top and starts again. He gets his break in life when a pudding-faced young man named Paul Sunday (Paul Dano) visits him and says he knows where oil is to be found, and will share this information for a price. The oil is to be found on the Sunday family ranch, where Standard Oil has already been sniffing around, and Plainview obtains the drilling rights cheaply from old man Sunday. There is another son, named Eli, who is also played by Paul Dano, and either Eli and Paul are identical twins or the story is up to something shifty, since we never see them both at once.


Eli is an evangelical preacher whose only goal is to extract money from Plainview to build his church, the Church of the Third Revelation. Plainview goes along with him until the time comes to dedicate his first well. He has promised to allow Eli to bless it, but when the moment comes he pointedly ignores the youth, and a lifelong hatred is founded. In images starkly and magnificently created by cinematographer Robert Elswit and set designer Jack Fisk, we see the first shaky wells replaced by vast fields, all overseen by Plainview from the porch of a rude shack, where he sips whiskey more or less ceaselessly. There are accidents. Men are killed. His son is deafened when a well blows violently, and Plainview grows cold toward the boy; he needs him as a prop, but not as a magnet for sympathy.


The movie settles down, if that is the word, into a portrait of the two personalities, Plainview's and Eli Sunday's, striving for domination over their realms. The addition of Plainview's alleged half-brother (Kevin J. O'Connor) into this equation gives Plainview, at last, someone to confide in, although he confides mostly his universal hatred. That Plainview, by now a famous multimillionaire, would so quickly take this stranger at his word is incredible; certainly we do not. But by now Plainview is drifting from obsession through possession into madness, and at the end, like Kane, he drifts through a vast mansion like a ghost.


The performance by Day-Lewis may well win an Oscar nomination, and if he wins he should do the right thing in his acceptance speech and thank the late John Huston. His voice in the role seems like a frank imitation of Huston, right down to the cadences, the pauses, the seeming to confide. I interviewed Huston three times, and each time he spoke with elaborate courtesy, agreeing with everything, drawing out his sentences, and each time I could not rid myself of the conviction that his manner was masking impatience; it was his way of suffering a fool, which is to say, an interviewer. I have heard Peter O'Toole's famous imitation of Huston, but channeled through O'Toole he sounds heartier and friendlier and, usually, drunk. I imagine you had to know Huston pretty well before he let down his conversational guard.


"There Will Be Blood" is the kind of film that is easily called great. I am not sure of its greatness. It was filmed in the same area of Texas used by "No Country for Old Men," and that is a great film, and a perfect one. But "There Will Be Blood" is not perfect, and in its imperfections (its unbending characters, its lack of women or any reflection of ordinary society, its ending, its relentlessness) we may see its reach exceeding its grasp. Which is not a dishonorable thing.

Story: My friend, Luis, showed me this anime after I had to suffer through No Game No Life. I have heard of it from anime club, and it came to me that I saw the first episode in the club as well. I thought sports animes were the last thing I was going to be watching, but I found Free! to be super entertaining. It may seem very corny to outside viewers, but the series becomes more heartfelt when you come to understand why the characters are the way they are. I will admit that the ending to the first season made me go insane.I cried like a baby for hours. The whole series is basically about three high school friends who are trying to build a swim team at their high school because one of them, Haruka, has been in love with the sport since childhood and wants to relive the competition they took part of in elementary school along with Rin, a mutual friend who transferred to Australia and came back to the private school with a very cocky and bad attitude. For what it's worth, the story is a 9 out of 10. It's not perfect, but it's good.


Art: It's a sports anime for god's sake. The art is supposed to be focused on the bodies of the characters, of course. When I originally heard of this anime, I thought it was just going to be about fan service with boys in swim trunks or speedos. It turned out I was wrong. The only stripping of clothes you would see is Haruka changing into his swim pants whenever he spotted a pool or an ocean to swim in because that was basically the running joke of the whole series, seasons 1 and 2. The other running joke is when Rin's little sister and the team's new swim coach, Go, is always pointing out how attractive men are in their swim trunks, but she doesn't mention anything inappropriate whatsoever. Plus, I find Rin's sharklike teeth to be cool, and the guys muscles seemed realistic. The only compliant I have is that I know some swimmers are beefier than others, and this didn't portray much diversity in size, but that could also be because in Japan, most of the people are skinny, so I won't complain so much. As far as art goes, it's a full vote.


Sound: The opening theme is fun to listen to every once in a while, but I wouldn't listen to it constantly. However, the opening clips give you a sense of what the show is truly about, and it's bittersweet a bit, but it doesn't give away too much. The ending theme is what I love the most because it's so sweet. I would rate this 9 out of 10.


Character: Pretty much like Ouran, Free! has its group of tropes, but they do not center around one person. Haruka is the emotionless boy who is mostly focused on swimming "free," meaning freestyle. Makoto is the kind one who just wants everyone to get along, and he is Haruka's best friend, who is the master of the backstroke. Nagisa is the lolita boy type and best at the breaststroke. Rin is the tough guy with a broken guy. When he used to hang out with the others, he was the butterfly stroke to complete the team. Then, there's Rei, who is the Free! equivalent to Kyoya without the douchebagness on the side, who took place of Rin for competing at the butterfly. There are other characters who are enjoyable as well, especially Haruka, Makoto, Nagisa, and Rin's old swim coach. This fandom is full of gay shipping, and I don't get involved in it often because I only ship two people if they look as if they would actually work in the actual show. The only ship I will partake in is Rei and Nagisa. Well, yes, they are both first years and they ride home on the bus together on the way and back from school, but they have been super close ever since Nagisa convinced Rei to join their building swim team. They are more best friends like than Makoto and Haruka. The characters never disappoint when it comes to this show, so I rated this a full vote.


Enjoyment: I wasn't crazy about this anime than I was with Ouran and Black Bullet even though I did cry at the last episode of the first season. I mean, it's good, but there's not one thing that makes me go crazy over it. Would I watch it again? Sure. Do I highly recommend giving this show a try? Yes, I do. I promise that Free! won't kill you. For that, this gets a rating of 9 out 10.


Overall: The overall score of the anime is the rounded 9 out of 10. I'm not putting my judgement on you, but please at least watch the first episode of Free! before you judge it.

It was obviously meant to be fanservice and I watched it expecting as much. Unfortunately the muscles were way to much and made the characters less appealing as fanservice. As all sports anime it is suggestive and homoerotic, and in this regard it somewhat accomplished its goal effectively. The story and characters were extremely cheesy and over the top. Many of the situations were not believable, and as a swimmer, many of the issues they had while swimming were unrealistic and unrelatable. The story seemed effortless but was not the main function of this anime. Overall this was not terrible to watch, but many ofthe main plot points led to moments that were cringey to watch and difficult to get through.

The only outstanding thing from this anime can be summarized in the following sentence: The animation is beautiful.
Story: 5
Let me just say (mainly to those of you who have already watched this anime): Rin is probably the only reason why the plot even exists and moves forward. Which I find really annoying.
Anyways, the plot has two main parts.
1. Three characters of the main cast, Haruka, Nagisa, and Makoto form the Iwatobi High School Swim Club and attempt to recruit one more person in order for them to be considered an official club by their school.
2. The three characters, plus the one other guy they recruitednamed Rei, join a competition in order to get Rin back into their 'squad' so they can be friends again.


The storyline of Free! follows the very basic sports anime format with nothing special about it.



Characters: 6

There is a bit of character development in this anime, but it isn't very significant from what I see in the first season.

Haruka is my favorite character in this anime, probably because he reminds me of Kageyama (Haikyuu!!). 

But there really isn't anything unique about the characters of this anime.


Animation: 10

Like I said at the beginning, the animation of Free! is extremely beautiful and fitting for the genre. 

It is also the only thing which makes me think that this anime deserves a 7 overall.

I especially like the animation of the eyes and the water.



Sound: 7

The OP/EDs were pretty good, and BGM was put in the right places at the right moments, but there weren't any tracks that stood out to me.



Enjoyment: 6

Since it had a really basic story and not much character development, Free! was kind of boring at some parts, but I did enjoy the comedy they put in throughout the show.



A really mediocre anime overall, Free! has great animation and nothing else.

If you want to get better at drawing anime art or receive inspiration to draw from an anime, then I would recommend this show. But if you're here for a good sports anime, I would suggest you do yourself a favor by watching Haikyuu!! If there was just one sports anime to watch, it would be Haikyuu!!

I don’t know what you’d watch this show for. If you want to gawk at hot shirtless dudes, you can probably get a larger quantity of those elsewhere. If you genuinely want a story about homosexuality, you’re probably stuck with Yuri on Ice because this show isn’t going to give any of that. If you want gripping character drama or some kind of intense sports anime, there’s much better shows to watch.
Overall, this show is extremely boring to the point of aggravation. There’s nothing this show does that other products can’t and don’t do better. Aside from the animation, which has Kyoto Animation’s grubby littleperfection hands all over it. Even then, there are kyoani shows that have better animation and aren’t boring.

**WARNING: THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS AT THE SECTION "ITS ENDING"! IF YOU DON'T WANT TO HAVE IT RUINED FOR YOU, THEN SKIP THAT SECTION!**
(I'm reviewing season 1 and season 2 in this review, so sit back and enjoy it.)
This anime at first glimpse REALLY didn't excite me, but I was wrong. It was a wonderful surprise to see for a first impression into the sports anime world.
So, let's get started...
- FIRST IMPRESSIONS -
           6/10
When Haruka says the first few lines for the introduction, it was like a little pleasant surprise for me. Sure, it's notexactly the best but it caught my attention enough to continue the first episode. And by the end of it, I was more than surprised as to just how much I enjoyed it than to what I was expecting!


- STORY -

    5/10


The story is simple and very easy to follow. Not as original, but it's not bad at all. It was executed very well though, I'll give props to that. But really, there isn't much to talk about about the story. (What really drives this anime is more of the characters to be honest.)


- CHARACTERS -

        7/10


They really are the stars of the show, and probably the thing I mostly enjoyed about in the show. They're relatable and very entertaining! (I'm only going to showcase the main five which were Haru, Makoto, Rei, Rin, and Nagisa due to the fact that there were lots of characters. But trust me, every character blended in very well in the series!)


Haru - He was by far the most interesting out of all of them. What with his addiction (or you might as well call his love) for water and the fact that he strips whenever he even sees water that's large enough for him to dive into no matter what situation he's in, I incredibly loved him for being so calm in most of the things he's been put through! But he really did have some development throughout season 1 and 2, which I appreciate very much as well.


Makoto - The friendly giant, I'd say. He's Haruka's best friend and is more like the Mom of the group. I really loved how he worries over Haru and the rest of the crew. Even his flustered moments were very enjoyable! Although not as much development for him as Haru, he did get quite a bit and was even a major requirement for Haru's as well!


Nagisa - He's the shota of the group, kind of generic but real sweet. He even adds some shipping references for the fanbase to enjoy (myself included.) I enjoyed how he was basically the light that lit the firework onto the whole swim club idea and even encouraging for another person (*cough*Rei*cough*) into joining them. And even though he's almost happy nonstop, he did have quite the depth to him later on.


Rei - I guess he's the opposite to Nagisa, more strategic than carefree. But for an original character, I really thought he was a character from the source (the light novel series). He really fit in! His character development I'd say was the second most noticeable (with him being rather reluctant but soon warms up to swimming in general overtime.) And his "BEAUTIFUL" thing really made it for me.


Rin - I'd say that Rin really had changed throughout the series! At first I was like "Ohhhhhh no not one of these people again-" but slowly, I began to be rather attached to him. He wanted to be the best and had strong ambitions, but was a tad cocky at times (which I can definitely understand, but that does change.)


Overall the characters were just a good thing to have around, and I couldn't really imagine if any of them were missing.


- ART -

  9/10


Kyoto Animation had done wonderfully with this series! The water, lighting, movement, and just how everything was done was STUNNING! All of the competition scenes were amazing and keeps your eyes glued to the screen, and some of the symbolism through it was beautiful!


- SOUND -

    7/10


The sound was very good quality, but nothing too special to think about. I LOVED the voice acting though since it was very well done and the cast had suited each character perfectly. The OST isn't very memorable (I'm not counting the character songs, guys.) but it definitely isn't bad either.


- ITS ENDING -

       8/10


Now, both endings for each season were very satisfying and I was pretty happy with how it turned out. In the second season, it was more about Haru and Makoto (along with others) moving on since they were almost finished with high school. Haru didn't have anything in mind which was very problematic, and during a festival he even has a fight with Makoto about what he was going to do since graduation was coming so soon.  It ended with Haru finally being able to move on and become a professional swimmer and things had lit up from there. (From the run down swim club at Iwatobi turning into one of the popular clubs to join, and Makoto and Haru moving to Tokyo all happy to get on with their lives)

I'd say it was a great ending for the series as it had ended with a scene that was drawn in the beginning of the series in the first place and boy was it nice to see them grow up bit by bit!


- ENJOYMENT + CONCLUSION -


I'd like to say that although the story wasn't the most original I didn't regret watching it! I really loved the show for just the simplicity and its characters, and it did have a type of story that was easy to follow, it had pretty good pacing, amazing art, etc. 

Would I recommend it? Definitely if you have free time or if you just want something to watch just for the sake of watching. Would I recommend it for the plot? It'll depend on you but it's not OVERFLOWING with it.

Although I had some fun while watching the show, I think it wasn't for the good reasons.
There won't be any spoilers in my review. (Spoilers on a show about swimming ? Seriously ?)
The story is lame, I mean, you can't really expect any serious plot in this show, it could be possible with a show who does not focus mainly on swimming, but here it is so pushed this way that you won't see anything else that teenage boys who want to swim for 12 episodes.
Talking about this, it is impossible to stay serious watching this show and I really laughed a lot when itcame to the boys swimming, over-exaggeration is everywhere and they seem so serious about everything they do that it become hilarious. \n\n
To conclude : \n
Story is lame.\n
Art and sound is really good.\n
It's fun to watch when you don't want to be thinking.\n
I can't give more than a 3 because it's too serious about what it's talking about.

Water is a living thing. Lets get this out of the way I have not seen any sports anime prior to this, so I did not know what to expect but I was amazed by how much I enjoyed this show. I finished watching Free Iwatobi swim club in the duration of fourteen hours.
Free follows Haruka ,Makoto and Nagisa who are childhood friends wanting to revive the swimming club in high school.Along with new member Rei they enter contests train and encounter their old friend Rin. With regards to story it's pretty basic but it was entertaining to watch. The main strength of the showis its characters and all five main characters are unique and relatable in their own way. My personal favorites were Haruka because I felt the same way about swimming that he did when I was younger and I still do and Nagisa who was the funniest part of the show. I also really enjoyed the transformation of Rei throught the show. Also, they way the characters interacted with each other was great especially Haruka and Rin. A prime example of this is the sixth episode where it's just the main characters interacting with each other and learning the backstory of Makoto. Also, one of the best aspects of the show was showing how Rei fit in to the group  which was one of the best parts of the show.


Te art is fantastic particularly the swimming scenes, specifically the relay race in the final episode which was absolutely phenomenal and the character design and movements was also very nice. Kyoto Animation did a fantastic job with this show. The opening and the ending of the show were fantastic, with an intense opening and lighthearted ending totally fitting the theme of the show. The voice acting was also great.


Now the anime free is more than fan service, while the story may be melodramatic but the drama is handled very well which made the show quite emotional to watch.Aside from the lack of some of the backstories of the characters and some side characters who I didn't really care for this first season was phenomenal.

I'm a young girl here - so my opinion will be different from most others.
I found this Anime to be really good considering the fact that most Anime nowadays are harem.
The reason that it's a 9 is mostly because it was guys. I am so freaking tired of harem anime with boobs bouncing everywhere. Don't get me wrong - some are actually good, some though.
The story of Rin and Haru is amazingly well developed. You could also keep track of the plot and what's going on. I really enjoyed this swimming Anime, even though I am not good at swimming in real life.
I fell inlove with all the characters, especially Nagisa. I loved the "We're all boys with girly names!" thing! They were all so adorable.\n\n
There is nothing I have to complain about except the fan-service side of the story - I'm okay with gay people, but it sort of is taking over - but not enough to ruin everything.

Cute story about childhood friends reconciling together. Kyoto Animation does a great job on the animation of the water and biceps, and all the characters have a lot of energy throughout the show, making things fun and interesting to watch.
As far as the story goes, it's an understandable story, but one where the dialogue doesn't play out to its fullest potential. Several times, we see the characters talk about mundane things or repeat things in serious contexts that left me wanting more depth. People go to great lengths at times to do or say relatively simple things.
Like how Kyoto Animation's highschool K-On girls don't talkabout boys, Free boys don't talk about girls. Maybe they're just too busy thinking about swimming with other guys all the time, but in both cases it makes it that much less believable for high school aged boys.\n\n
I really did not like the ending. Not to spoil anything, but it essentially felt like it was  all about Rin, with Rei more or less just filling the space he left empty in their group. Everyone's considerate, but in the end I'd hate to be Rei.\n\n
But all in all characters were all fun (except Haru is almost like Mikasa from Attack on Titan, with a one-track mind on swimming Free to her one-track mind on Eren), the animation was great, and I enjoyed seeing a protagonist group of guys doing fun things (like Daily Lives of High School Boys). Can't wait for the next season!

Spoiler free! 
I think that no matter what, Free! is a really fun anime to watch. It's only 12 episodes, so of course, there is nothing to compare with other anime that is actually based of a manga, since Free! is based off of a light novel. Considering the fact that Free! wasn't even supposed to be an anime, it's held up pretty well. 
I started watching Free! very impressed with how well written it was even with the excessive fanservice. I think that the way they animate the water is really beautiful. You can really feel the motivation behind the characters' thoughts. The storylinestarts out filled with tension and I think that most people will want to continue watching to see what happens. Overall though, I don't think the overall plot is anything very revolutionary, and does very much fall into the slice of life genre with maybe more angst. 


I think that later on, the plot does get a little lazy however, which is why I stopped taking it as seriously and just started watching casually to see what happens. The reason that the plot falls flat I think, is because the characters that have been so carefully developed are then used in the later episodes in these really melodramatic ways that made me cringe. For example, the way that some expressions were animated took away from what the anime was trying to communicate. 


Also adding to the silliness of the later episodes was the ridiculous soundtrack...there were moments where the music was just ???? completely inappropriate and laughable. Normally, I am fine with whatever music but even to my ears, there was just too much of a disconnect. 


Overall, though, I think that in the end I probably just expected too much of this anime from watching the first 3 or so episodes, since I hadn't read the light novel. If you watch the series just expecting something a little fun, I think you would like this. The characters are even pretty amusing sometimes!

Free! was a series i wasn't particularly excited about. the synopsis did not draw my attention, and the images and video clips i saw in previews made me think it was just going to be a fan service anime targeting a female audience. Of course i decided to give it a watch anyways, as an animator i appreciated what i saw in the water effects and figured if nothing else that would be worth my while.
Having watched Free! all the way, i have to say this: if you have any remote interest in it, ragardless of how off putting the manservice is to you, giveit a chance. the first episode lays on the manservice a bit thick with suggestive camera pans and plenty of pool side topless dudes with amazing bodies, but that gets significantly toned down later on in the series around episode 3 or 4. One of the things that made it work even for me as a guy was having Gou, or Kou as she prefers being called, present at the scene. Her reactions somehow level out the manservice by providing you with a squealing fangirl if you don't have one on hand, making you feel like it's ok to watch this because there's a girl here. Sort of like how it's ok to walk into a girly store at the mall with a girl, but feels wrong when a guy goes in alone.


Visually KyotoAni does it yet again. everything in this show looks absolutely gorgeous from the background art to the characters. Of the most notable things are the water effects and the character animation and posing. During the backstroke event when the swimmers dive off the block you can feel the arch in their backs. the physicality just shows so well. When they hit the surface you can feel the water wrapping around them.


The characters are ok as they never get too in depth about them. The character development was also fairly weak but given that this anime is what it is it didn't need to be any more than that. Nagisa possibly being the most stereotypical of the characters, being the overly girly cute boy.


The story was actually pretty good. it's not amazing but it worked for the sake of a sports anime revolving around swimming. None of the problems really feel like big problems, in fact they are actually pretty trivial, but they do well enough telling the story that you can sort of understand why it's such a big deal to the characters. It's not dark, it's not particularly serious, and it's got just a light touch of drama.


All in all Free! was something fun for the summer, so if you've got the time i suggest you dive right in!

This will be a short review since I don't have many things to say.

- Because I'm an amateur swimmer/sportsperson myself and this anime made me want to keep training, whenever I see charactersin anime that are training hard I get really motivated (kinda weird but I think I'm not the only one). \n
- Because the beautiful scenery and animation were very soothing to watch\n
- Because the story focuses around relationships of friendship and healthy competition, something you rarely see irl nowadays \n
- Because it reminded me of a real life situation where a pool in my hometown had to close and me and my friends had no other place where we could swim, haha.\n\n
I wholeheartedly recommend this anime to anyone

Although it admitedly isn't a particularly deep series, it's charm points being quite obviously fit teenage boys and their relationships, Free! is very well executed, engaging and overall every enjoyable.
The Story
Free is about Nanase Haruka, a teenage boy who likes water more then land, and his experience in re-etering the previously abandoned world of competitive swimming due to the return of his chilhood friend, and now enemy, Matsuoka Rin. Haruka reluctantly forms the Iwatobi Swim club at his school with he and Rin's old teammates Nagisa and Makoto, Rin's sister Gou and new member that can't really swim Rei. Rin joins the rival schools swimteam.

One of the best parts of this series is trying to figure out what's going on in Rin's head, as the viewer is never quite sure what his true intentions are until almost the last episode.

There's plenty of comedy, drama, shonen ai (not really, but seriously, they are all so gay) and semi-tragedy to enjoy.

A couple of stories appear to repeat themselves, and a suprising number of the swimmers have childhood trauma with people drowning, which they sort of seem to forget about.

It's nothing spectacular, but the characters make up for it.


The Characters

It's easy to assign roles to the main characters of Free. Haruka is the silent serious one, Rin is the devilish one, Makoto is the gentle loyal friend, Nagisa is the silly one and Rei is the geek. That doesn't stop them from being extermely enjoyable to watch and likeable, thought.

The side characters are unfortunately a little more lacking. Gou is a female pervert, obsessed with guys muscles (even her brother's), Ama-sensei, the advisor, is a little yandere, Nitori, Rin's kohai, is all senpai notice me, etc...

I'm eternally grateful for KyoAni's decision not to put Gou in a bikini at any point, it's extremely refreshing to have a non ecchi anime for girls to enjoy.


The Animation

Animation is KyoAni. I don't really need to say much more then that, flawless. The amount of detail put into the water graphics is ridiculous. 


The Sound

The opeing theme for the first season of Free is possibly one of the catchiest songs of anime 2013. The voice acting is good, althought quite a few of the minor characters sound quite similar. The voice for Rin is particularly good.


Overall conclusion

If you are looking for something light hearted, cheerful, emotional and well animated that can be watched fairly quickly and plesurably, Free is the show for you. Just don't go expecting any amazing plot twists, trust me, there aren't any.

Let's put aside the biased of the Male and Female demographic because that doesn't make a Series more "GOOD" or "AWESOME". I watch Anime for entertainment and Story, I do not care If It is catered to a certain Audience. Free, for some reason was very anticipated many Female viewers prior to Its airing. Many Male viewers began hating on Free saying that Its "GAY" even prior to Its premiere date. I'm a Male myself and I will be honest with you, I did enjoy Free from Episode 1 up to Episode 12. Yes, there were some Fan Services in the Anime, but nothing forme to drop the Anime as a whole because I love the Story, Music, and Art. K-ON! was catered to Male viewers as well, yet the Females don't complain about It. I don't know what makes Free hated by Males. Don't many of us guys enjoy having a good looking Body? If so, why hate Free just for that? 


[STORY] 8.0 /// [CHARACTER] 7.0

I was expecting Free to be another Plotless Anime because of Its SPORTS genre. Keep in mind, I'm not an avid watcher of the Sports Genre in anime so this is technically my first time watching an Anime from that Genre. It proved to be wrong when I saw 1-2 Episodes where It did have the potential to have a great Storyline. There was absolutely nothing wrong with the Plot. Everything was well fleshed and easy for many viewers will understand. The Ending was absolutely well done no doubt. 


[ART/SOUND] 10.0

Animated by the same Company who did Kanon, Clannad, Hyouka, Chuunibyou, and K-ON! another excellent job for Kyoto Animation for producing such amazing Art for Free. This Anime does share some similar Art Style from Hyouka and a little bit from Chuunibyou, especially the character designs. The Water and the Environments are top notch. Watching it in 720p looked absolutely beautiful. I was also impressed with the Music that was used in the Background. Mixed with Acoustic tunes to some Electronics like Dubstep that fits well with the Scenes. 


To Sum it all up, Free is not a bad Anime to watch. If you are a Male viewer who wants to watch It, just watch It. Don't be ashamed to watch It just because Its for Females. I can't say for Fan Services, but again don't let that stop you. With that said, that's all I have to say for my Review of Free. And I do look forward to Next Season in 2014.

Four young friends (Makoto, Nagisa, Rin, and Haruka) win a trophy for swimming a relay together, but everything seems to fall apart when Rin leaves for Australia to join a prestigious swim club there. When he returns in high school, the boys work to put together a new school swimming team with the help of Rin’s sister, Gou (or is it Kou?), and Rei, a new calculations-obsessed member, but find Rin to be a very different person.
It’s really the humor and the relationships that steal the show here, that and the level of fanservice: the use of subversive female-gaze camera shots to display gorgeous half-nakedmale bodies with water sparkling or dripping off of them. And the fact that the guys all bond by being boys with girly names.\n\n
The delicious rivalry between Haruka and Rin, the mystery of what happened between them to change their personalities, the way they all take care of each other, the reason Haruka only swims freestyle, and generally the strong (and supremely slashy!) friendships make this a delightful anime even if you have no interest in swimming.

I admit that I found Free! too late, but I enjoyed the anime well. The artwork is pretty detailed, especially the guys here. However, the story itself is pretty good, although I do admit that the anime aren't subtle enough to hold the story and explanations. It's pretty obvious that the anime held the explanation about Nanase and Rin for too long and it's obvious. But the ending is pretty mainstream, since Iwatobi SC gave Rin a chance to swim, and got disqualified for doing so, even if they won.


The sound. Sometimes I wonder if it's my headphone that is too good, or the sound is actually pretty good. The soundtrack is marvelous, and the soundtrack has alot of details in it. The soundtrack illustrate the anime pretty well.

I have written a blog entry about this show but I figured I would give a review a try and see how this turns out. For the most part, this show is probably one of my favorites as is the second season, Eternal Summer; the storyline, the artwork, and the character development in both seasons are really what sealed the deal. For me, this is the first show that I have watched where I felt real emotion and sympathy for each one of the characters, even the characters that you "were not supposed to like" and that just proves how spot on the development ofeach of the characters really are; it is extremely telling when you can feel any kind of emotion for every character in a show and it is incredibly rare to find. 


The show makes it so easy to become invested into everything that encompasses the story and it does not take long before you are fully submerged into the crystal blue water, similar to the characters you get to know, and suddenly you want to be in that world with them. Suddenly, you start to care and you begin to think about swimming in a way you never did before and it is wonderfully beautiful. After finishing both seasons, I found myself in my bed at two in the morning crying my eyes out because I was so overcome with this overwhelming sadness and nostalgia. For a while I could not figure out where these emotions where coming from but then it hit me: it was because, after those twenty five episodes, I had gotten so deeply involved in everything that was happening that those emotions completely took over my entire being. The wins, the losses, every friendship; I felt everything. The next thing I know I am looking that the ending screen of the entire show and I had only one thought going through my head, "I do not want it to end. It cannot end." For me that is the most wonderful thought to have after watching an Anime.


Now, I understand and completely respect the fact that this kind of Anime is not for everyone and not everyone is into sports Anime; everyone is entitled to their own opinion and their thoughts are completely valid; however, I think that this show is definitely a show that people should check out because I do not think it will disappoint anyone. It is still a very good show regardless of whether or not it is traditionally popular.

STORY 
Free! is a slice-of-life comedy type anime. The story was very simplistic, and revolved around a theme of friendship/comradery. No complicated story lines or fillers. There was good development within the characters throughout the story. The beginning wasn't very catchy, but the ending was fulfilling. I felt that it wrapped up the story nicely and it felt complete.
CHARACTERS
Each person had their unique personalities, like Haru's water fetish, which contributed to the comedic aspect of the anime. 
The male characters being really close friends + having their shirts off most of the time (obviously b/c they are swimmers) apparently threw some viewers off, making themthink its "gay/homo" or "female fan service." Ignore these people. They are going over the top and making a big deal out of nothing.\n\n
ART/ ANIMATION\n
Fantastic. The detail put into every character's slim, but muscular bodies were amazing. I thought they really reflect how real life swimmers bodies are built. Also, animation of water was insane. How they made the water look so good is beyond me.\n\n
MUSIC\n
The ending song was really catchy! I caught myself dancing to it a few times. The opening song was meh...\n\n
OVERALL\n
Personally, I enjoyed this anime. It was definitely worth my time and I recommend everyone to watch it!

Not going to lie--when I first started this series, I wasn't really expecting much, because of the pre-airing hype. I'm a fujoshi, but I pretty much expected this to be just fanservice without much profoundness to it. Boooyy I was wrong.
This series /does/ have a lot of fanservice, but it actually has a point to it, which was a pleasant surprise for me. This /is/ a sports anime, technically, but it focuses more on the relationships and friendships between the characters, and Haru and Rin's character growth than it does the actual sport.
I insist on addressing some of my annoyances with the other reviews here.It is not "a yaoi", the term is used just as "yaoi" (side note, yaoi is also not an adjective). Another, yaoi (in western definition) refers to the explicit male-male works. In Japan, yaoi is mostly only used for smut-without-plot doujinshi. The term itself literally just means that it's gratuitous PWP. Free! is either shounen or shoujo. It has no relevance to yaoi. Please stop misusing the term.


I wouldn't have minded more in-depth incorporation of the sport. Overall, great series (though the most terrible fandom I've ever seen--from ship wars to staff/translator bashing). The character designs/personalities are great (except for nitori--the teardrop mole is overrated go home and if he says senpai one more time I will shove a bottle of chlorine down his throat), though not outstanding, which is probably part of the reason this show isn't in my top favourites. Makoto is by far the most popular character in this series, but it seems most people are in denial about his co-dependency issues and that trait of his where when he always gives into Haru first is not a good trait to have. I'm not saying they shouldn't enjoy his character, but I do wish they'd do so without denying parts of his character that the staff have even acknowledged. Though I personally find him to be a weak character. Rin, and the other characters, are also not perfect, which I acknowledge. Except Rei. Rei is perfect in every way. From his horrifying fashion sense to his beautiful super-saiyan-level-amazing screaming in the drama CDs. Also, A+++++ voice acting for Hirakawa and Mamoru.

The instrumentals are generally lovely, and the first OP song is legendary. The Engrish in some of the songs is horrible, however. (For god's sake, Japanese musicians have too little respect for other languages.) The character songs are poorly composed (save for Mamoru's, which had decent melodies, and whose singing is the only one really worthwhile to listen to imo).

The animation, is, needless to say, simply outstanding. The animation for swimming is very accurate, which I appreciate. It's pretty much perfect there. 


I have to say I'm not a huge fan of kuudere (e.g. Ayanami Rei, Kuroko) like Haru, but Haru isn't a flat character by any means, nor is he just there to look pretty. By the end of S2 especially, he grows tremendously as a character. His journey on his (avoidance of his) path to find a dream is extremely relateable. He's generally very apathetic, but Rin and his friends manage to spark change in that. The story takes us on Haru's path to find what it means to be truly "free", which if that's not profound, I don't know what is. However, Haru as a character himself is difficult for me to care about long-term, like one of those movies that you forget about after leaving the theatre. I wouldn't say he's a weak character, but he's not terribly interesting.

Makoto.... has nice legs. I don't have much else to say here about him other than I'm glad for his character growth in S2. (Honestly, I have less problems with him than I do for his fans.) I'm a huge fan of Yamato Nadeshiko types (e.g. Hinata, Sinon, Orihime, etc.) but I do not believe Makoto deserves to be called that. Yamato Nadeshiko are, at the core, with strong mental strength (or achieve strong mental strength), and Makoto is actually rather weak and vulnerable inside.

Nagisa is a devil in sheep's clothing. Not as much as the fandom jokingly makes him out to be (lol Thugisa), but beware. We learn about him more in S2, which I'd love to expand on, but this is on S1. Anyway, he's adorable, but that's not all he is.

Rei is the most hilarious character in this series by far. He's completely adorkable, and a total goofball, but he can say some pretty wise things, and he's a huge cataylst for change in both Haru and Rin. I relate to him a lot, too, including reasons such as that I also can't bloody swim no matter what I do lol. We share a similar appreciation for beauty (aesthetic, and in my case, also otherwise). Even if you don't care for stories of male bonds, I highly suggest watching the series even if just for him.

S1 focuses a lot more on Rin's character growth than Haru's. Rin's character has the most depth by far, and he sticks. A lot of people make him out to be a lot more of an arrogant smug prick than he actually is, though--please keep in mind that much of what we see of him in S1 isn't actually his true self (is that a spoiler? ...I don't think so. .....ah well. I just don't want anyone to ingrain any wrong first impressions). That said, he's not perfect either, of course. But you can ignore the people who keep harping on him as "abusive" for literally no good reason.


I find it rather jarring that anyone would say Hyouka is a romance, but there's a parallel scene in Free with the flowing sakura with all the same camera angles and the shoujo wind, and yet people say this show is "not gay at all". (keeping the identities in the following passage vague to avoid spoilers)  Nevermind all the rest of the very, very obvious fujoshi-baiting (almost kiss-CPR trope, hello?), and the two people very obviously in love with Haru, made especially obvious in the novel ("my shining/waterbird"), and one comment by Sousuke in s2 that Rin didn't even deny, and Rin's whole hotel bed speech. Or the "or should we sleep together in the same bed like when we were children?" in the drama CD. And then they actually do sleep together in the same bed (happy accident) later in S2. Yes, they can think whatever they want, but misinforming people with "not gay at all" is just rather sigh-worthy. Only one male->male affection is made 100% canon (verbalized) in this series, and there are no canonically gay relationships, but this show is far from "not gay at all". It makes me really sad that I can describe so many romantic scenes between males to people, while not stating their genders, and when the other party is told, especially if they're males, they automatically assume I'm talking about a male and a female in love. But when they watch the show first, it's always "it's just bromance". You people talk about "I don’t feel like turning this review into a gay rights rant", but it's just your brand of heteronormativity and being in denial about things you don't want to see. Power to you if you don't like it; but don't spread it just because you're uncomfortable.


One of the things I find most amusing was the hype expectations of their characters, vs the actual personalities of the characters. Especially Rei. We were all expecting the typical studious tsundere meganekko, and instead we got a HUGE DORK (still my favourite character). The shota we all expected to be a 2-dimensional fluffy puppy turned out to be a little shnit. Etc.

First of all, this series isn't "gay" as others might think or as it appears to be. Second, this is a swimming anime hence, the guys here are on their "swimsuits" 80% of the time. Third, this series is about bonds of friendship.
Art: Though I don't give particular attention to the "art" of any animation, I gotta say for the sake of this review that the art in this anime is surely beautiful. The characters, scenery's and even the water are well drawn with colors that pop and thus is visually appealing. 
Sound: One of the elements that give life to any animation imo isthe sound, so the sound is more important to me than the art. In this series, the music is great and whether it be comical to emotional, the tracks fit the scenes perfectly. The opening track brings up the hype while the ED track is just okay to me. \n\n
Character : Alright, all the characters are very likable though the series mainly focus on the development of two characters. The others also get their shining moments but the female characters doesn't really get much development.\n\n
Story and Enjoyment : Again, though the story mainly focuses on the relationship of two characters,  I for one actually enjoyed this show. There were funny moments, annoying moments and emotional moments. And more than that, the friendship that the characters share allowed them to grow, change and be selfless. For people who takes interest in stories of friendship (male friendship in particular), sports and some eye-candy (with the art), this is a very good anime to see.
